number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2015
												As an off-and-on fan of rogue-lite/like games, I am always torn determining the amount of skill and the amount of luck you will find in these games. Unseen probabilities within games are something I always am wary of complaining about when I could've had some really bad luck.However, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game where I blamed myself more so when I made errors than blame the odds against me. This is the first rogue-LIKE where I could tell I was improving myself, and it's the first one in the genre where the demands on the player's skill were mandatory.Because with each failure through the familiarity of the controls and the coodrination of my fingers to the bass-line of the music I was reading the enemy telegraphed moves. Or adjusting myself to a new tempo-change. Or finding myself becoming at ease with the bizarre control-scheme. (Minus the DDR pad.)The Rogue-Like With A BeatThe novelty of this game is that it takes the game of Rogue and gives it a beat. Literally. The musical theme is not solely an aesthetic. The gameplay is interwoven into the music itself. From the way you move around/attack to the amount of time you have to explore the dungeons. Once the song ends, you are dropped to the next stage. (There are red-bars to show that the song is nearing its end.)Every movement/action you make is managed by moving in-time of the music. You and every enemy move according to that rule, which gives the game a charming tactical feel while sometimes relying on you thinking on the fly. Enemies attack in a specific manner which usually results in them having an "off-beat" to strike them. If you simply attack head-on with no regard, you'll die a lot.If that sounds too convulted about how the combat works, let me rephrase it like this: You are the metronome; the music is what you need to match (as the tempo can increase and decrease); and the enemies are the other instruments in play. The game plays more like reading a music sheet than another rogue-like game. The controls are the first major obstacle to get over, which you can play this game legitimately with either a controller or keyboard (or a DDR pad, which has an easier difficulty just for itself). To get the best experience, I would suggest you map your directional keys separate from your combo keys. There are too many moments towards Zone 2 and onwards that rely on twichy relfexes in-time with the music to coordinate your fingers in combinations.Thankfully, the game isn't too demanding on you maintaining a constant rhythm. If you're like me, I struggle to keep a rhythm going longer than a few seconds without going faster or slower than expected. The game is leniant on being perfect, but you cannot spam your movements. The game simply won't let you, and you won't be able to obtain the modifiers to your gold (and modified items) if you don't keep the beat.I was able to get past the first zone on my KB alone, but the second stage's music tripped me up when I had to make those split-second motions to drop a bomb or use an item. Switching out the combos to other keys fixed it for me, and I would strongly suggest that if you play the game with a controller you get the directional pad some love.Practice Makes PerfectionMany rogue-lites rely too much on probabilites of which you can and cannot control (FTL). Others rely on attention to details of your item and the levels to spot those small benefits to get you to the end (Binding of Isaac). Crypt of the NecroDancer is a part of the trend where they provide permanent progression across chunks of the game. (There is a story mode for purists who want to play a more traditional rogue-like experience. However, I chose the permanent item/stat increases as I am not the best at these type of games.)There are stat increases and new loot to give your next playthrough something to change it up as well as possibly improving your odds. None of which are mandatory--I wouldn't think of going without them--if you are good enough at the game to read your enemies' movements.Outside of the item/stat increases, you also have another means to improve your next game: Practice rooms.You have a training room for enemies and minibosses that unlocks with a certain amount of kills for every enemy, a boss pratice room (unlocked via currency you accumulate in every run, diamonds), and a weapon-training selection screen to practice in either room. These rooms are unlocked by finding trapped tradders within Zone 1 and 2 and unlocking them with the Golden Master Key.Having a story-mode option and a perma-progression system as choices is the best compromise as both the purists who prefer to learn the game on their own and everyone else has the means to finish the game. But it ain't so easy, nor free.The bosses cost in-game currency to unlock. And you can't simply practice on all the enemies from the get-go--you have to kill each enemy type several times to unlock them. Simply, you can't cheat yourself out of a challenge without investing first.(And if you don't like some items, you can discard them for diamonds with the Janitor).It Ain't No StepmaniaPerhaps the game's own lacking feature is the infamous difficulty of its genre. The game doesn't feel that hard.Make no mistake; the game is difficult for all the right reasons, and you will die a lot. But there are plenty of items to circumnavigate the game's difficulty, and some enemies that make me wonder how fair the game truly is.For example, blood items let you regain your health, slowly, with enough kills chained together. There are also magic spells that might stun enemies, blast horrizontally, or give you some buffs to become overpowered in some situations. I would chalk these up to limitations of making a novel game without all its polish.Some enemies also break the rules. There are some enemies that move in diagonal movements, which you are never allowed to do. The red-dragons also seem unfair without a "ranged" weapon (weapons that extend beyond one-tile, such as long-swords or broad-swords) to get around taking damage.Zone 2 seems to have a sharp difficulty spike because you start off with nothing (even if you finish Zone 1). So expect that you may still have some bad runs when you begin new zones.The only feature of this game I hadn't tried is adding your music into the game. This game's music was tailored for the game, and I am sure slow songs will break it while Megalovania will result in a very bad time.Shake Your Groove ThangThis is one of few rogue-likes I'll always come back to because it's a fun experience. It's not a brutal old-schooling, nor is it coddling to the new players. The game's sense of challenge makes an otherwirse creative deviation into a worthwhile game of its own.And how can you not have fun dancing on a plastic pad like an idiot?(Kudos to the devs who put this through Early Access and finished the game. As well as for adding new content to the game itself with no DLCs. If they have another product through Early Access, be sure to give them a second glance.)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
28, 2015
												This is one of the best games I've ever played and it's easily my favorite indie game to ever come out. 10/10Necrodancer follows the roguelike genre, the mechanics are simple in themselves, a tile based roguelike in which you only only move to the beat of the music. That is where the simplicity ends.In addition, each enemy has their own movement pattern, following the beats of the music. There are traps laying on the ground that control movement, send you down to the next level and ones that flat out damage you. All of this mixed together creates complex and rewarding gameplay that keeps you coming back.Being a rythm based roguelike, music is key and the game delivers in its soundtrack. The music was composed by Danny B, known for composing games such as Super Meat Boy and Binding of Issac. The tracks are perfectly suited to the style of game and will keep your head bobbing as you move to the beat. In addition, there are remixed versions of the game's soundtrack done by A_Rival and FamilyJules7x, which allow for more variety and they sound fantastic as well.But what if you get sick of the music? There is an option to import your own MP3 files into the game so you can tap along to your favorite songs as your progress through the game.The art style, while another pixel art type of deal, looks great. The enemies are unique, it's easy to distinguish them apart and easily identify what you're going to be going up against. Even after you play the game with the default character Candence, there are many more characters availible to mix up the gameplay and keep you coming back. If that wasn't enough, there is a daily challenge mode to compete in everyday to hone your skills and try to climb to the top of the leadboards; or you could just compete with your friends.I can go on and on about this game, I adore it, the gameplay, the visuals and the soundtrack amaze me, and it all blends into this perfect package of a game.

content:
er 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Inventive mashup of the roguelike/rythm game genres. Most innovative game I have played in a long time. If you think you will enjoy this game, I would definitely recommend it.Amazing soundtrack!Heaps of replay valueChallenging gameplay which rewards skillful execution & game knowledgeItems are really well balanced and there are very few (if any) totally useless itemsThe different weapons are varied and fun to useThere aren't many items that radically change how you approach the game from a tactical standpoint more of a mechanical/execution standpoint Balanced learning curveRange of characters that vary in difficulty/playstylePixel art may seem a little over-done in the indie genre but it is very well executed in this game and suits the tone/atmosphereDevs are adding a lot of content during early accessMinor issuesIf you are looking to play the game with your own music, the interface for adding your own music is not well suited for exploring a large music directoryThe default controller mapping is not great but it does support custom control mapping for controllers

content:
6, 2015
												Crypt of the Nercodancer is a Dungeon Crawler game mixed in with a Rythem Movement system, as in you have to move to the beat of the song.the game itself is pretty simple and Really easy to understand, The artstyle is really nice and pretty clean looking aswell and the soundtrack is easily one of the best, all 3 of them, original, EDM and Metal. Edit: 2 more were added a while ago! A chiptune soundtrack by the same person who made the shovel knight soundtrack & a Synthwave Soundtrack by Girlfriend records, Never fail to amaze with the different styles of remixes!There are 10 Characters total, Each every different things, like bolt who moves at double the speed, or Aria who can't get hit or miss a beat (as in dies in 1 hit or missing a single beat.)There are a bunch of different enemies, which also move to the beat with different patterns which are easy to understand, Each as moving every 2 beats or lunging forward after being hit once or even teleporting the player. Even if you're someone who isn't great with hearing/listening, there's a guideline sort of thing at the buttom of the screen, which you could use to learn the beat.Its a great game and i'm amazed the Devs Created this unique game. Easily Recommedable to friends, Especially with the OSTs.

content:
er 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Give this review a reed, it will only take a minuet. Whatever expectations you have for this game are going to fall flat. The idea behind it is just so clef-er, and even in it's alpha I don't even C any minor flaws. Much less any major ones! It's especially fun if keeping a beat is your forte, and if it's giving you treble don't fret about it, you'll get it. I am no lyre, this game is amazing!Real ReviewI have to say it now, this is my new favorite rougelike game. It is  amazing ! Once you start you are not going to want to put it down. The visuals are great and apealing to look at, and all the enemies dance! How awesome is that!? And the music- OOOOH THE MUSIC -it just works...so well. I actually started typing this review before, and when I typed, "And the soundtrac-" I immediately went and bought it without realizing it would erase what I had typed! It's that good. I completely recommend buying it. And then there's the shopkeeper. His voice is the most beautiful thing you can hear while fending off skeletons that have their hands in the air like they just don't care! One thing that is terrible great about it is that when you die, it's your fault. It's because you weren't paying close enough attention, or because you didn't react fast enough. There are some times when I die that I just have to take rest...sorry, and mourn my own stupidity. The game almost never cheats you. Unless there's a red dragon. I'm sorry, that's fate, it's going to kill you. There are some enemies that seem like they do, but maybe I just don't understand them. *cough* bats *cough*[EDIT] I do have a give a fair warning though, the difficulty spikes between levels 1 and 2, and I can't even imagine 3.After playing some more, I have a few things I would like to see improved:*I think the shield skeletons need an "arms up"-like frame in their animation, it can sometimes be unclear whether they will attack or not*The red dragon is way too hard. Maybe I just suck*The ability to go from Level 1 to level 2 and so on in one run, like in daily challenges. The later levels are just way too hard to start from scratch and hope you get lucky. **More permanent upgrades, the dungeon master is hardly used after the first hour**A option/item that makes the shopkeeper always singing (perhaps if it's an item, you can see him or the music notes all the time)See, not even very many :)I haven't completed it, so maybe some things I just haven't found yet. Improvements marked ** are something I'd see coming into player after the full release

Early Access Review
								Wow.  Just... Wow.  Where do I begin?  A buddy of mine got me this for X-mas and I've been playing it non stop.Great Retro Pixel Artwork.  Interesting and addicting game mechanics.  Plus a soundtrack that makes you hit restart just to listen to it again.Danny Baranowsky does again, and writes rockin', catchy tunes that'll be stuck in your head for days.The game is still in Beta, but that doesn't stop it from being fun one bit. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2016
EVERYBODY DO THE FLOP!After the unfair atrocity against humanity that is Spelunky, I jumped away from the rouge-lite bandwagon and started to avoid this kind of games entirely. You cannot imagine the frustration which that cursed game gave me with its extreme unpredictability of annoying enemies, dirt-poor and mostly useless item pool, random stuff blowing up in your face without your fault etc.Good thing that Crypt of the Necrodancer fixes nearly everything I listed above. Listening to the Overwhelmingly Positive rating on Steam apparently is sometimes a good idea!You can imagine the game as a mix of classic dungeon-crawling games, generic rouge-lite games, chess and DanceDance Revolution. During the proper gameplay player makes moves on tiled dungeons, trying to move, attack, defend, explore and explode to the bounce of the sickest beats. You can consider beats as a split-second turns when everybody on the level makes their action and the outcome is immediately apparent. Either you move into enemy-infested tile and attack it or they move into yours, dealing damage etc. Every action in the game is bound to the beat of boogey-man looking Necrodancer who is the main villain of this really barebones and after-thought of the story.CotN fixes EVERYTHING Spelunky screwed up. Aside of non-common bat types, every enemy has a predicable pattern you can exploit. Items you acquire throughout your adventure are varied, allowing different playstyles and strategies. There is not nigh-required Jet-Pack and Shotgun combo you need in Spelunky because in Necrodancer many combinations of items can ease the difficulty significantly. Game also doesn't screw you up unfairly too often. Most of the time you lose because of your own mistakes and not because somebody else angered the shopkeeper or that Yeti made a bouncing ping-pong ball of you, sapping your whole life in the process. You are still fragile in the game, but healing is much less a pain-in-the-butt process andit's much more reliable. Crypt still has some fair share of annoying enemies but those are much more manageable than in the other rouge-lites. There are also single-level modes (allows story progression with checkpoints between zones) and additional, harder characters, so both less-hardcores and harder that hard-hardcores are welcomed here.As for problems of the NecroDancer: bats still exist. Enemies sometimes come in crowds, making difficulty in tackling them safely. Item descriptions are vague and show up only when you approach them from tile away, from which you need to jump off immediately, forcing you to needless experimentation until you memorize the effects. Level themes are extremely generic (Mine/Forest/Ice-Fire World/Temple) which is a missed opportunity in comparison to the rest of the game (like enemies which are really imaginative with bouncy and enjoyable animations and charm).In short, Crypt of the Necrodancer in an enchanting game, full of enjoyable gameplay, good inventive ideas and incredible music (which really goes without saying that loud. Bought the soundtracks... All of them). It's must-have on the nearest occasion for everybody who isn't tone-deaf, without the sense of rhythm or satisfaction from fair challenge.Also, f*** Spelunky.

content:
r 20, 2015
												This game fooled me, but in a good way. I was expecting a cute gimmick - a music game disguised as a rogue-like. Instead, I got a solid dungeon crawler with a musical twist.Crypt of the Necrodancer is the first game to combine two of my favorite things; EDM and The Undead. The style is cute, cohesive and somehow works without jumping the shark, which is hard to do for such an odd mix.+'s * Gameplay is solid and difficult, but not because of the musical aspect. "Spinning Plates" and managing many simple enemy patterns together takes awareness, practice and planning.* The beat is there as a turn-timer of sorts. By forcing the decisions to be quick, there's opportunities for mistakes (and therefore mastery/learning!) * Several characters with different styles, rogue-like style.* TLC put into the production value, even considering a more throwback/pixel art style.* Soundtrack is fantastic.-'s* While there's a variety of characters, the game's core gameplay has to eliminate a lot of the dungeon options and items that make the full-run version fun, meaning many of the alternate characters are less interesting than the default.* It's said before, but Aria is extremely punishing to play. This is where it truely becomes a rhythm game, but it also has the problems listed above. Not a deal-breaker, but a sore spot.Highly recommend this if you're a fan of strange mash-ups that work, or want a dungeon delver with its own unique feel and flavor. The game holds up without the music, but is greatly enhanced by having it. :)

								This game is absolutely amazing. The music will enter your head and refuse to leave, but for once, that's a good thing. The controls are extremely simple to learn, but deviously tricky to master. Even though it can get extremely hard, there's also easier modes and built-in systems for practicing against that enemy that you can't seem to get past, or even if you just wanna relax and explore a bit. To add on top of how beautiful the game is and entrancing the music can be, there is plenty of room for customization through the Workshop, or even just your own music! There is so much to say about this game, so many things to explore, and it's not even entirely done yet! If you like rhythm games, rougelikes, or even just games that have plenty to explore, get this game!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
2015
												You'll like this if :You are a fan of rogue likesLike SpelunkyAppreciate good game soundtracksYou'll hate this is :You have no rhythm and things like DDR drive you nutsGet bored with casual quick gamesThink old school graphics are horribleCrypt of the Necrodancer is a light rogue like game that owes a lot of its design philosophy to Spelunky. It does away with the depth of most roguelikes and instead concentrates on serving up a bite size piece of dungeon crawling in a challenging cute form, with many of the game design elements from Spelunky directly converted into its top down view point.So far, so similar.But CotND has a gimmick up its sleeve. The soundtrack. Everything in the game moves to the beat of the soundtrack, animations, movement, attacks - even your own input has to move to the beat of the soundtrack, like some mad version of Dance Dance Revolution where each step lets you explore further into the dungeon.Move out of step with the beat and you will be punished - losing bonus and also potentially missing your chance to move or attack. Learn to step with the beat, learn how the monsters move with the beat, and suddenly you will be popping along to this fiendishly addictive game.If the idea of playing a roguelike to the sound of a beat sounds weird - it kind of is. And I'll admit I wasn't entirely sure if this would turn out to be a flop or a cool idea. But once you play it, it just makes sense, and adds a very unique aspect to the game - that of timing. Where you have to move to the beat - staying still just isn't an option, and yet a move will push you into the path of a deadly foe, or out of striking range of a target. A new dimension of just how to "wait" or move in such a way as to hit an enemy becomes part of the game.The soundtrack itself that supports the main gimmick of the game is absolutely top notch, and there are a few great touches to the game - such as the singing shopkeepers - that just make this game work really very well indeed.An all round excellent experiment in combining the winning formula of Spelunky with a top down roguelike all to the beat of a soundtrack. Don't be put off because this game is kind of... left field. It manages to weld everything together beautifully, and is definitely a game where you will just want One More Try, because This Time, I've Got It.

content:
5, 2016
												A beautiful blend of dungeon crawler and rhythm-based gameplay that shows progress isn't the only reward, not with a smashing sountrack like this.To start, I have put over 80hrs in on the PS4 version. That is how I learned of this game. I had to buy it ASAP because that is just how good it is. Even got it on my smartphone and spent about 20 hours on that version.This game tasks you with crawling through a dungeon while slaying monsters to get to the end. Simple enough right? Wrong. To do anything (move, attack, use item) you must do it to the rhythm of the music that is unique to that floor of that dungeon. Sound fun yet? The monsters also have their own movement style that goes to th music too so now you have to learn their pattern to be able to take them out without getting hurt.There are plenty of things to unlock too, like weapons, weapon types, character boosts, and magic items. There are also different characters to unlock in the game that very drasticallly change up how you play your game!Have I mentioned the soundtrack you play to is absolutely amazing?No dungeon crawler is as good as this one. I fear none may ever be. Get out there and buy this!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												"Crypt of the Necrodancer" is best described as a fusion of "Mystery Dungeon" and "Dance Dance Revolution" games. You are tasked to explore a dungeon full of threats, traps and treasures while keeping in tune with the current music of the level.It takes its core gameplay from both roguelike and rhythm game genres. As a roguelike, you crawl through procedurally generated levels and suffer permanent death if killed. Each attempt grants a unique experience as you battle monsters, gather equipment and explore the dungeon. As a rhythm game, you must also ensure that all of your character's movements and actions are in tune with the music. Maintaining perfect rhythm gives you additional bonuses, while missing beats penalizes you in various ways.The game has a great soundtrack that changes between levels. The visuals are generally colorful and exciting, but you have the option to disable the bright disco floor if you find it too distracting. The story cut-scenes are simple but well-written and appropriate for the setting. There are a number of unlockable characters and options to allow different playstyles. You can even add custom music or play using dance-pad mode.Overall, I found "Crypt of the Necrodancer" as a fun, refreshing and original experience. Easy to learn but difficult to master, I would recommend the game to both roguelike and rhythm game enthusiasts.

er 28, 2016
Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game that intrigued me from the first moment I heard about it.Just about everything in this game is absolutly charming; from the overall visual design, to smaller details like the singing shopkeep, you can realy feel the love and passion that went in to this project. However the thing that truly sets NecroDancer apart from any other game is how it brilliantly blends the dungeon crawler and rhythm game genres into something new, and in my opinion, something greater than the sum of its parts.As a part of the Steam Awards, Valve featured The “We Didn’t Think Of Everything” Award, which allows us the chance to nominate the games that might not fit into an existing category. As such, I would like to nominate Crypt of the NecroDancer for The “Most Innovative Gameplay Mechanics” Award 2016. I have certainly loved playing this game, and I hope that you will enjoy it too!

content:
er 23, 2016
												Disclaimer. Do not get this game if you like your fancy 100% game completion rate, as this game's achievements will tear it to shreds. They are not glitched or anything, but some are unbelievably hard.But regardless it is one of the best games I ever played. It is almost perfect, though there are a few flaws here and there, mostly minor.The biggest thing is that playing one of the hardest characters is a decent part of the game's story, most of the characters aren't "easy" per say, but dying in one hit to anything, including missing a beat is a little extreme to have to go through to progress the story, even if you don't take the hardcore route and do it by playing the zones individually.I heard that you can do it co-op with Bard as your partner to make getting the last bits of the story more reasonable, but I haven't tried it and even if it helps, you're still in for hell of a ride. (I decided against playing that character until I get a few more achievements)Another thing is how one of the challenge characters work, the one where you have to play twice as fast, but the speed of the music stays the same, which is odd surprising that this is a game where you have to play along with the beats of the song and it doesn't quite work right in that case, but apparently there's a mod for that.And the last nitpick being how the singing shopkeeper vocals clash with the metal version of the soundtrack.But regardless it's a great game with good music and providing a unique and fun experience.

content:
r 6, 2015
												Warning to all who dare to enter the Crypt - If you have no internal metronome, turn back now. Seriously, you need to be able to hold a beat to even consider playing this game in full. And yes, this is an important distinction - I've seen several attempted runs from someone who didn't, they were very short lived. Another warning - If you have any music preferences, they're about to be formatted.Anyways, Crypt of the Necrodancer is a roguelike rhythm game. The roguelike takes precedence for the most part, but it's good to keep a rhythm-game mentality. The gameplay can be a bit tricky at first, but superb once you get the hang of it. The actual progression is a bit basic (not uncommon for roguelikes), but that's not too major a problem. The biggest issue most people have with the game is that the rhythm-based controls are a bit gimmicky or unwieldy, but I had very little problems with them and they didn't get in my way too much.But enough about the gameplay. I'm writing this review to commend the SOUNDTRACK. This game's BGM alone is worth the $15 admission fee, and that's a bargain. I've been known to listen to the soundtrack on repeat for hours on end, and am working on burning the soundtrack onto a CD as I type this. And if the planets align and someone is born who doesn't like the music - you can set your own too.So in summary: If you think you can manage the gameplay, get the full game. If you don't think you can manage it, already have the game, or need a new soundtrack to listen to in your spare time, buy the soundtrack. And if by some strange coincidence you neither want this game's gameplay nor it's soundtrack, then and ONLY then will I permit you to not touch this game.What are you waiting for... pick up the beat!

content:
10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game brings Rouge like Dungeon exploration and Rhythm Games Together into the game we call "Crypt of the NecroDancer". Bringing you into 3 Different zones each containing their own sort of enemies. Each zone containing 3 levels and 1 Boss Level. Each boss having their own rhythm, keeping you on feet trying to learn how each of them move and react. At the moment you can play as 4 different characters. Some might have a easier way of playing, or a harder challenge to conqour. The game is currently in early access but is still worth buying and playing for yourself.This game will keep you curious for a long time thinking of what this game will bring once it gets out early access.

content:
, 2015
												Easily one of the best rhythm games to come out EVER. CoTND is a procedurally generated dungeon crawler with the difficulty and addictiveness of Binding of Isaac, with, imo, a killer soundtrack. This is probably because the music was made by the same guy but, I digress. And if for some reason you hate the music (or you get sick of dying and hearing the same bloody song from level 1 over and over again like I do (inb4 'git good')) you can substitute the level songs with your own music. You play at Cadence, one of several musically-named individuals who must make their way through the titular Crypt for their each individual reasons, which is fun but the true awesomeness lies in the music-related combat and sweet pixel art visuals. That being said the game is hard. It's really hard. The good news is with a few proper upgrades you can become veritably unstoppable in any of the worlds. The learning curve drops into a cliff about the time you meet the Red Dragon, who can take you out with a single well-timed fire breath from across the map, and he'll show up every now and again in Zone 1.Easy to learn and hard to master are how I would describe this game, and would definitely recommend it unless you're known to break things if you get easily frustrated. Mice and keyboards are expensive.

Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game that intrigued me from the first moment I heard about it.Just about everything in this game is absolutly charming; from the overall visual design, to smaller details like the singing shopkeep, you can realy feel the love and passion that went in to this project. However the thing that truly sets NecroDancer apart from any other game is how it brilliantly blends the dungeon crawler and rhythm game genres into something new, and in my opinion, something greater than the sum of its parts.As a part of the Steam Awards, Valve featured The “We Didn’t Think Of Everything” Award, which allows us the chance to nominate the games that might not fit into an existing category. As such, I would like to nominate Crypt of the NecroDancer for The “Most Innovative Gameplay Mechanics” Award 2016. I have certainly loved playing this game, and I hope that you will enjoy it too!

content:
er 23, 2016
												Disclaimer. Do not get this game if you like your fancy 100% game completion rate, as this game's achievements will tear it to shreds. They are not glitched or anything, but some are unbelievably hard.But regardless it is one of the best games I ever played. It is almost perfect, though there are a few flaws here and there, mostly minor.The biggest thing is that playing one of the hardest characters is a decent part of the game's story, most of the characters aren't "easy" per say, but dying in one hit to anything, including missing a beat is a little extreme to have to go through to progress the story, even if you don't take the hardcore route and do it by playing the zones individually.I heard that you can do it co-op with Bard as your partner to make getting the last bits of the story more reasonable, but I haven't tried it and even if it helps, you're still in for hell of a ride. (I decided against playing that character until I get a few more achievements)Another thing is how one of the challenge characters work, the one where you have to play twice as fast, but the speed of the music stays the same, which is odd surprising that this is a game where you have to play along with the beats of the song and it doesn't quite work right in that case, but apparently there's a mod for that.And the last nitpick being how the singing shopkeeper vocals clash with the metal version of the soundtrack.But regardless it's a great game with good music and providing a unique and fun experience.

												10/10 and more if I could give it. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 1, 2016
												I'm not a huge fan of turn-based games, the careful calculation isn't my cup of tea outside a bit of casual play. I like action roguelikes, which give me a challenge I can quickly work through, but by nature there'll always be a glut of deaths that seem more random chance than my fault.This game solves both problems. By making it technically turn-based but setting each turn to a less-than-half-second timer, every move is forseeable in advance; but you have to keep moving. So it beats me up but every time it does I realize I "obviously" could have just used that bomb, or staggered one more turn.Beating the final story is simply one of the most satisfying thing I've done because I felt like I had legitimately EARNED that victory through-and-through. Quick-thinking, experience, and timing got me there, not just lucky drops. That feeling is what makes this easily one of my favorite games I've ever played. But getting your face stomped in repeatedly in hopes of one day achieving the goal isn't for everyone. I'm just in the right place for this game.Also, good job on making the music bearable even after hearing it for 28+ hours

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2016
												This is one of the only Early Access games that I have purchased very early on. It also happens to be the first early access that I have absolutely loved from the beginning and it's probably one of the only early access games that I purchased that actually came out as a complete game.Crypt of the Necrodancer immediately caught my eye because of its unique gameplay (or was it just an impulse buy because of the pun?). It's essentially a Rythm Roguelike game. It has most of the elements of a Rogue-like, except you have to stay on beat!The soundtrack is absolutely amazing (and now offered in 3 different variations!) and the game is deceivingly difficult. It's very easy to pick up, very hard to master and highly addictive.Even having played through the first 3 zones countless time while I waited for the fourth one to come out, then all four a bunch of times when it did, I still enjoy playing this game from time to time (I have played a lot more than Steam indicates.)I often despise randomly generated levels but in this game it works very well and follow a set of logical rules. Each level will always be similar while always offering something new. There are tons of different items that will help you on your runs and different characters that provide different challenges when you get bored of Cadence, the main character.A very charming and challenging game with a lot of replayability, fully worth the 16.99$.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2015
												Completionists, stay away.  There are things that are practically impossible to obtain.Roguelike purists, also stay away.  The game mechanics aren't extremely deep.Otherwise?  As long as you can tap to a metronome (or at least learn to) and do enjoy action, I highly recommend this game.Crypt of the NecroDancer, at its core, is a rhythm-based action with roguelite and dungeon crawler elements.  People have compared this game to games such as Faster Than Light and Spelunky; I really enjoyed the former and felt iffy about the latter, and after 350+ hours, I don't know if I can really stop playing NecroDancer just yet.It's very easy to pick up and understand the core gameplay; one or two local players act to the beat (with only the arrow keys), and everything else responds to your movements on the same beat, allowing you to plan for the next beat.  Getting dropped into the first zone after the tutorial level, you're introduced to a small variety of items, learning about this and that, buying and picking up things to figure out what your favorites are, and dealing with a small variety of enemies.  Items definitely make things easier, but it's absolutely possible to finish everything and low% a run with only default gear.(By the way, if you want to have a sense of genuine curiosity, go into the options and disable "show item hints".)And once you inevitably die, it's not so bad.  There's almost always a way out of whatever predicament you managed to get yourself into, and you sensibly chuckle at it and figure you'll do better next time.You slowly progress, saving a few unfortunate NPCs from cages, buying new things with diamonds and slowly expanding the pool of items you get to find and use during runs.  You finally manage to get the boss down, start to learn why Cadence is in this dungeon of dance, and then you're back to square one, figuring out the patterns in the completely new world that is Zone 2.  And you work through it, because holy crap is that Danny Baranowsky soundtrack fantastic and motivating.And you keep at it.  Some things change completely, some things don't, and some things get flipped upside-down and force you to change tactics.Occasionally, you take a break from Cadence and pick up a different character.  Oh yeah, there's other ways to play the game in Zone 1 again, and some new strategies for enemies you've seen before.  All the normal characters are interesting to work with in their own way.Once you feel that you've finished the important stuff, a variety of things open up.  Score runs?  Speedruns?  Sure thing, try to see how well you can do on the boards and in the daily challenge runs.  Low%?  Go for that, if you want to.  In terms of replayability, you get about as much as Spelunky -- everything generally stays the same, but for some reason the variations between runs always gets you coming back for more.Mods are a thing, to some extent.  At the very least, many resources can be replaced and custom levels are supported and supported through Steam Workshop.  That's about it, though; there's no way to add in completely new items and content just yet.Remember what I said about completionists?  Yeah, if you want to 100% this game legitimately, forget about it.  The developers added in a character that even they think is impossible.  There's absolutely nothing except bragging rights and an achievement to gain from completing a run as said character (unlike in, say, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth), so you're not missing out on too much otherwise.It's been great watching this game only get better from Early Access; Brace Yourself Games has been nothing less than incredible with regular development and responsive to the community.  If you haven't been driven away from reading this yet, it's absolutely worth more than the $15 that it's listed for.

content:

												Crypt of the Necrodancer is a unique game involving following the beat of the music, into your attacking and your movement. You can't just rush from one end to the exit in 3 seconds, you have to time your movements with the beat otherwise it wont work. Not to mention the amazing soundtrack this game has with Danny B, A_Rival, Familyjules7X, and others! There is now a new dlc being worked on and it is amazing, it is worth $6.99 or however much it costs when i'm writing this, There are new characters, new modes, new weapons, new shrines and enemies and there is more coming! They are constantly updating this game. Also it is never the same run every run, You will always find new weapons and tools with different dungeon layouts and boss orders, you can almost never get bored with the game always having a new run to offer along with amazing music.

content:
0, 2015
												Got on steam sale, was hesitant to buy and am SO glad I did.  This is a fantastic rhythm game.  The focus is about unlocking powerup spawns and learning each enemy while grooving to an awesome beat.  The dungeons are randomly generated, but each zone has its own theme which remains the same in any mode (music, enemies, and art).  There are also different game modes; they are not drastically different but definately different enough to change it up a bit.  This game is something kinda new because of the rythm based movement, but DEF worth trying out. 10/10 recommend getting this game if unsure- I know I was and I don't regret this purchase at all!

												I have been interested in Crypt of the NecroDancer for a long while then. All my friends who I have asked about it who have played the game say its really great. Now that I have tried the game I say I agree. NecroDancer is two parts rougelike one part dungeon crawler with a sprinkle of beat matching game sprinkled in. Every action throughout Necrodancer is done to the beat of each levels song. You try to move down floors through the dungeons while collecting loot, fighting monsters and just generally trying not to die to some sort of nasty trap.I feel like Crypt of the NecroDancer is a well rounded challenging game and I recommend it to any rougelike fans.

Besides, skin workshop is still confusing, gameplay is really difficult fortunately dungeon's songs are awesome, therefore I can listen same song over and over without getting tired. Consequently, It deserves every penny of the price because we are being witness and piece of rhythm games revolution

content:
, 2016
It's Dangerous to Dance AloneRouge-Lite games have been done to death within the past couple of years. Retro Aestetic? CheckPermadeath? CheckGenerated Dungeon? CheckWhat makes Crypt of the Necrodancer stand out in my opinion?well..It's rhythm based. I love rhythm based games which was the main reason for me buying this.It's also harder than it looks. In order to move you gotta hit the arrow keys (or whatever button you wish to map to) along with the beat. Unlike some Rouge-Lite's: losing doesnt feel like a waste of time. You just want to return and try to nail the rythm with your finger tips. If you collect enough Diamonds you can buy loot in your lobby and the diamondsremain in your inventory until you restart a new zone.If you somehow are a genius and have perfect rythm and beat the game there's always daily challenges to back once a day to further up your skills.Also if you like the idea of a DDR dance pad then there's a dance pad mode to improve your cardio and dance if you want to be the Patrick Swayze of Crypt of the Nectrodancer.

content:
2015
												Completionists, stay away.  There are things that are practically impossible to obtain.Roguelike purists, also stay away.  The game mechanics aren't extremely deep.Otherwise?  As long as you can tap to a metronome (or at least learn to) and do enjoy action, I highly recommend this game.Crypt of the NecroDancer, at its core, is a rhythm-based action with roguelite and dungeon crawler elements.  People have compared this game to games such as Faster Than Light and Spelunky; I really enjoyed the former and felt iffy about the latter, and after 350+ hours, I don't know if I can really stop playing NecroDancer just yet.It's very easy to pick up and understand the core gameplay; one or two local players act to the beat (with only the arrow keys), and everything else responds to your movements on the same beat, allowing you to plan for the next beat.  Getting dropped into the first zone after the tutorial level, you're introduced to a small variety of items, learning about this and that, buying and picking up things to figure out what your favorites are, and dealing with a small variety of enemies.  Items definitely make things easier, but it's absolutely possible to finish everything and low% a run with only default gear.(By the way, if you want to have a sense of genuine curiosity, go into the options and disable "show item hints".)And once you inevitably die, it's not so bad.  There's almost always a way out of whatever predicament you managed to get yourself into, and you sensibly chuckle at it and figure you'll do better next time.You slowly progress, saving a few unfortunate NPCs from cages, buying new things with diamonds and slowly expanding the pool of items you get to find and use during runs.  You finally manage to get the boss down, start to learn why Cadence is in this dungeon of dance, and then you're back to square one, figuring out the patterns in the completely new world that is Zone 2.  And you work through it, because holy crap is that Danny Baranowsky soundtrack fantastic and motivating.And you keep at it.  Some things change completely, some things don't, and some things get flipped upside-down and force you to change tactics.Occasionally, you take a break from Cadence and pick up a different character.  Oh yeah, there's other ways to play the game in Zone 1 again, and some new strategies for enemies you've seen before.  All the normal characters are interesting to work with in their own way.Once you feel that you've finished the important stuff, a variety of things open up.  Score runs?  Speedruns?  Sure thing, try to see how well you can do on the boards and in the daily challenge runs.  Low%?  Go for that, if you want to.  In terms of replayability, you get about as much as Spelunky -- everything generally stays the same, but for some reason the variations between runs always gets you coming back for more.Mods are a thing, to some extent.  At the very least, many resources can be replaced and custom levels are supported and supported through Steam Workshop.  That's about it, though; there's no way to add in completely new items and content just yet.Remember what I said about completionists?  Yeah, if you want to 100% this game legitimately, forget about it.  The developers added in a character that even they think is impossible.  There's absolutely nothing except bragging rights and an achievement to gain from completing a run as said character (unlike in, say, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth), so you're not missing out on too much otherwise.It's been great watching this game only get better from Early Access; Brace Yourself Games has been nothing less than incredible with regular development and responsive to the community.  If you haven't been driven away from reading this yet, it's absolutely worth more than the $15 that it's listed for.

												Starting off by saying that I'm playing this under Linux, and no problems whatsoever with the game.Decided to give "CotND" a whirl, after reading the reviews, looking at game-play videos, and taking advantage of a 75% off sale. I'm full of praise for the game. It's lots of fun, it has great tunes, it's addictive, you want to play it 'just one more time', and it is no push-over. After about 8 hours of play I finally managed to beat Zone 1. And I'm no way near beating Zone 2 yet (and then there's Zone 3...)They did a fantastic job of designing the game, with a vast variety of different items all of which alter how the game plays and how you shift strategies to get further. For instance, spear weapons give you more reach, and broadsword weapons allow you to do a very wide attack. But what does a Monocle do, what about Glass items, Cheese, heh.Every little detail is so well crafted. For instance, if you want to repeat the same level again and again, then there is 'seed' mode where you type in a 'seed' word (e.g. 'random') and then get to play the same thing over and over again, but then if you want to play entirely randomly (rogue-like), with no repeating whatsoever - then just go for the regular play.I could say plenty more... but let's just summarise with this: It's a big thumbs up from me.

content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Necrodancer delivers the electronic beats and a horde of monsters to defeat. Our unlikely herione, Cadance, boldly foregoes the suggested years of dance training and rushes in to save her own heart and vanquish a legendary foe.Roommate 1: "What are you playing, Legend of Zelda?"Roommate 2: "That actually looks like a decent rhythm game."Brace Yourself Games has successfully combined a couple of genres into something you won't expect to be fun into something outright addictive. Every level is randomly generated and challenging in its own right, but there is always a bunch of orderly and easy to learn patterns to every enemy you will encounter. This isn't a game for everyone, but it's a game worth trying despite the fact that it isn't fully developed yet.Sure, the game is a bunch of pixels and the learning curve is a bit harsh. But the satisfaction of beating a single level keeps me coming back for another beating, the default music is awesome, and the game never ceases to be interesting. I don't know if I'll ever get good at it, but it inspires me to no end as a game-designer-in-training. I would regret never having played this game more than I regret a lot of other things.

												For the rogue-like and rhythm fans alike, this game provides an amazing soundtrack, lots of replay ability with its randomly generated levels, items, and bosses, as well as amazing pixel art! If you don't have this game, buy it now, it's worth every penny! (And for the people who are a bit tight when it comes to pecuniary measures, don't worry, this game has been on sale a lot these past few days!) I'd recommend this to any friend or family member who wants to have a great, grooving time! I'm extremely glad I can be a part of this community too. I honestly need to start a real life group that's filled with people who love the game as much as I do, because Crypt of the NecroDancer is one of my favorite games due to the amount of detail the sound crew, pixel artists, and everyone else had done (I also have to thank the person who made the puns for everyone of the enemy names personally, they're amazing without a doubt)! Although I only have around 50 hours of playing the game, you can bet on the shopkeeper's amazing voice that you'll love it too. And if the wide variety of characters, weapons, etc. aren't enough for you, you can even download mods! A personal favorite of my being the Captain Falcon reskins with sound, truly amazing.) With a great community and even greater team, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a must have. And now, after the real review is over, I must now make a musical pun to balance out the silliness (and to show respect for the beautiful, beautiful man/woman/team who came up with the puns.). Let's see... oh, I have one! If you do not like this game for whatever reason, then you can kindly and respectfully kiss my brass! Heh, I don't mean to toot my own horn or anything, but musical puns are the 'key' to success! (But back to seriousness, 10 out of 10, would recommend to everyone who plays video games and/or loves music.)

content:
, 2015
												Rythm-based roguelike dungeon crawler, where you have to press buttons to the beat of the music to move each turn.Putting aside the rythm gimmick, the game plays like a simple grid-based dungeon crawler. As you slay monsters and descend through the crypt, you find a variety of equipable items that upgrade your character. Enemy attacks come in predictable patterns which can be dodged, and your attacks likewise hit with different patterns depending on what weapon you use. The tactics aren't complicated, but it's easy to slip up when you're tasked with making several moves per second. The combination of speed, timing, and strategy is unique and feels very satisfying once you get the hang of it.The story, told through cutscenes, is unremarkable but not bad. Furthermore, the voice acting and pixel art are good, and the music is stellar. The game's focus is on its mechanics, but it manages to cobble together a compelling atmosphere as well.Playing each of the game's four zones one by one is relatively easy and allows you to buy upgrades between runs, but the marathon "all zones mode" is much more challenging. There are also several playable characters, each with their own mechanics, as well as local co-op multiplayer.A hugely successful experiment - lots of fun.

content:
31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the NecroDancer is a fantastic entry into the Roguelike genre, so let's break it down.The primary draw of the game is the great music and how it is worked into the mechanics. In order to succeed you must move and attack to the beat of the song assigned for the floor. This is both simple and wickedly difficult to keep up, but the better you manage the more gold coins you earn due to a multiplier effect.Stats in most roguelikes depend heavily on luck in finding items or leveling up, but in CotND you can definitely succeed with just the basic starter gear. The reason why is because the game doesn't rely on huge health pools and in fact most monsters can be killed in a single hit and the only monster you MUST kill is the boss on the final floor. Playing conservatively is a very viable tactic because there are many ways to advance to the next floor and there is no leveling up that requires killing monsters.Each dungeon, at least for the moment, is three dane-a-thons of fun and a final boss. So game sessions are short and failure does not leave that typical bitter taste.There's a light quirky sense of humor, especially when the shopkeeper starts belting out tunes with the music. Colors are bright and all the monsters get a little dance-y jig which makes things pretty playful. If you're doing well you also get magical disco lighting all over the dungeon, huzzah!This is the Roguelike for people who like music and a shorter, more meaningful play session. The game itself isn't super long, but the random elements and multiple character types will keep you as busy as you would like.Final Score: A-

content:
ry 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the Necrodancer is the game where you think you're good at beating down monsters to the beat... then you unlock hardcore mode. You think of this as impossible as Zone 3 is one giant zerg rush of skeleton horses and elemental enemies. Nonetheless you try it anyway and manage to get some decent gear. Then a red dragon comes along and says "♥♥♥♥ you!" and you get one shot by a fireball because you can't do the sacred red dragon dance at that moment. (That's my life, i cri evertim ;;) But seriously, this game is amazing in many aspects. It's hard to find a game where a particular character dies from picking up GOLD, of all things! Since the levels are randomly generated there is no true pattern to the game and permanent death is indeed a thing. So that guy that dies from picking up gold? He's no exception, better watch your step! Oh yeah, and the only way you can move/attack/dig/open chests is by hitting the arrow key in the direction that you want to go on the beat of the song that's playing. There's a nice little tutorial in-game for that, though. However, there is one thing that bugs me about Crypt of the Necrodancer. That is, the diamonds that are used to purchase items to be put into the item pool for non-hardcore runs. It would make more sense to have everything unlocked already, like hardcore does, but you are forced to buy it using diamonds you find during non-hardcore runs. It's a bit more harmful than helpful and everything should just be unlocked for you to use when it's found. Despite that, this game is well worth your time. I've got 60+ hours and counting clocked into Crypt of the Necrodancer and it's not like I'll be stopping anytime soon. If you like challenging games, get this game. If you like rogue-likes, get this game. If you like rhythm based games, get this game. The point is, just buy the freaking game! What're you waiting for? Scroll back up and click that "Add to cart" button!

I encountered cleverly designed enemies and challenges that tested my brains as much as they tested my skill. Even though the roguelike level of difficulty meant I died many times, I'd jump straight back onto that deadly dancefloor for another tango with trouble. Why, I could barely stop myself from playing this game just so I could write this review.Oh no, the music is starting again. The dance... the dance must go on!

content:
r 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								15 bucks might seem a bit steep for what looks like a simple pixel-art roguelike game, but trust me when I say this: BUY IT.  This a truly unique game, and although the mash-up between genres (roguelike and rhythm game) may seem strange at first glance, it works brilliantly here.  Danny Baranowsky killed it with his score - I find myself humming the songs in my head when I'm at work.  Gradually learning the different strategies for dealing with the various enemy types is extremely rewarding, as you'll eventually work your way up from dying every time you run into your first miniboss to being able to complete runs in 'hardcore' mode, where the real fun is.  Add in daily challenge runs, multiple unlockable characters that dramatically change elements of the gameplay, and more content to come, and you'll be getting way more than your money's worth.Easily the best game I've picked up in a long time.  A+, 100%, 5/5 etc.  And it's only in alpha!

content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								Brilliant. I was glad i instantly bought this game after hearing so many good things about it. For a while i've watched few people play this game and from what i could gather, it really held up to all it's promises.I bought this game and figured since it has Co op, i could try it out with a friend of mine, and we had a blast.The music is amazing and the whole Roguelike feel mixed with Rhytm was an excellent mixture.The graphics are pleasent for the eyes and keeps a retro feel while having upbeat chiptune esque sounds compossed by the brilliant artist Danny Baranowsky who is also known for doing music for Binding of Isaac and Super meat boy.Alright, let me get into the details of what you're getting yourself into.This game feels rewarding even when you die there will always be upgrades which adds to your progress.There are items to buy and bunch of stuff to unlock to add even more replayabillity including a hardcore mode.Co Op is twice the fun and there were no issues to be had since the screen pans out the further apart both players are.Enemies have patterns which are easily memorized by repeating the game through trail and errors and the same goes for all of the traps and mini bosses and main bosses of the game.But here comes minor nitpicks since no game in this universe is flawless, so don't take this the wrong way.This game can be unforgiving to people who have a hard time adjusting to the sense of beats and rhytms but there is a steady learning curve which seems to work.The controllers input works fine but i can't seem to get the ''start'' button to work at times so i have to use Keyboard whenever i wan't to continue in a zone when i can't use my diamonds.Like i said, this game is amazing and i'm glad that it exists, don't let these minor faults ruin the experience for you.I'm rating it a solid 9/10 and recomend it, especially for Roguelike/Rhytm game fans or Binding of Isaac fans.

content:
ber 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a really, really good game. The art style is fantastic, resembling the prettiest SNES game you never played, and the soundtrack by Danny B (of the Binding of Isaac fame) is incredible - as it needs to be, since music is the core of the game. Everything you do in the game, you can only do on the beat: moving, attacking, etc. It might sound like a strange concept, but it's the foundation for an incredibly solid game design. As a roguelike-like with persistant elements (similar to Rogue Legacy), you start each game in the lobby, where you can spend diamonds to unlock new items or bonuses, and choose which game mode you want to play. Presently, there are four game zones (each consisting of 3 levels and a boss fight), a local co-op mode, a daily challenge similar to Spelunky, and several different options for difficulty modifications, including a hardcore mode, or a "dance pad." Yep, you heard that right - you can buy and hook up your own DDR style dance mat for this game. A controller or the keyboard works just fine too, though, with four keys (up, down, left, right) being all you need to control the game. Apart from the beat, the gameplay will be familiar to anyone who has played a roguelike dungeon crawler: delve, loot, destroy. I honestly wasn't expecting to enjoy the game as much as I did, but I have to say - it's incredible. Pick it up if you've ever enjoyed the roguelike genre, and don't worry too much about the "Early Access" state, or the curious core mechanic - once you get used to it, you'll love this game. NOW OONTZ FORTH TO VICTORY, YOUNG DANCE WARRIORS.

y 1, 2016
												I'm not a huge fan of turn-based games, the careful calculation isn't my cup of tea outside a bit of casual play. I like action roguelikes, which give me a challenge I can quickly work through, but by nature there'll always be a glut of deaths that seem more random chance than my fault.This game solves both problems. By making it technically turn-based but setting each turn to a less-than-half-second timer, every move is forseeable in advance; but you have to keep moving. So it beats me up but every time it does I realize I "obviously" could have just used that bomb, or staggered one more turn.Beating the final story is simply one of the most satisfying thing I've done because I felt like I had legitimately EARNED that victory through-and-through. Quick-thinking, experience, and timing got me there, not just lucky drops. That feeling is what makes this easily one of my favorite games I've ever played. But getting your face stomped in repeatedly in hopes of one day achieving the goal isn't for everyone. I'm just in the right place for this game.Also, good job on making the music bearable even after hearing it for 28+ hours

content:
ry 21, 2016
												This is one of the only Early Access games that I have purchased very early on. It also happens to be the first early access that I have absolutely loved from the beginning and it's probably one of the only early access games that I purchased that actually came out as a complete game.Crypt of the Necrodancer immediately caught my eye because of its unique gameplay (or was it just an impulse buy because of the pun?). It's essentially a Rythm Roguelike game. It has most of the elements of a Rogue-like, except you have to stay on beat!The soundtrack is absolutely amazing (and now offered in 3 different variations!) and the game is deceivingly difficult. It's very easy to pick up, very hard to master and highly addictive.Even having played through the first 3 zones countless time while I waited for the fourth one to come out, then all four a bunch of times when it did, I still enjoy playing this game from time to time (I have played a lot more than Steam indicates.)I often despise randomly generated levels but in this game it works very well and follow a set of logical rules. Each level will always be similar while always offering something new. There are tons of different items that will help you on your runs and different characters that provide different challenges when you get bored of Cadence, the main character.A very charming and challenging game with a lot of replayability, fully worth the 16.99$.

Product received for free
												It’s a fun game in which you use the beat of the music to move and advance further, think of it as the binding of Isaac but with a rhythm that you have to keep up with in order to move. Much like Isaac the game is fairly short per playthrough but highly challenging. There are a lot of items in the game that you can pick up as you play, most are different from eachother and provide different experiences depending on what items you have.Thanks to the game’s randomly generated dungeons and challenging nature, every playthrough feels unique and different giving the game good replay value.If you are a fan of tapping to the beat of your favourite music this game is for you. The amazing soundtrack by Dannyb and it’s remixes gives the game a ton of charm and if that isn’t enough, you can use your own music in the game as well.As you progress through the game you’ll unlock new characters both playable and non-playable ones.The non-playable characters sometimes offer items that make the game easier but some are for practicing certain enemies or bosses. Practicing is helpful for learning enemy patterns.The playable characters that you can unlock are often harder characters that offer a bigger challenge, this includes; a character with double speed/beats, a character that dies if he picks up money, one that can only use bombs and many more.The game is good, check it out if you haven't. <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 29, 2014
												Crypt of the NecroDancer is a dungeon - crawler with rogue - like elements... Yeah, I know. Go ahead. Sigh if you want to. It's okay. I'll wait. Yes, it's true. We're currently in a market hugely oversaturated with "dungeon-crawling roguelike" titles. But unlike many other games of its genre, NecroDancer manages to stand out and hold its own with its unique and very fun spin on the familiar idea.The premise is simple enough. You enter the first floor of a procedurally-generated dungeon, moving in four cardinal directions, fighting various monsters and finding random treasure items such as weapons, armor, spells and consumables. On each floor of the dungeon there's a shopkeeper you can do business with.Sounds very familiar, right? Well this is where NecroDancer does things differently. Everything you do in the dungeon, such as moving, fighting, using items, and digging through walls... you have to synchronize with the beat of the music. All of the enemies follow this rule too, and as a result you have a system that's fairly easy to pick up and very satisfying to master and tinker with. On your first few runs you'll be so concerned with keeping the beat that you'll just throw yourself headfirst into enemies and traps, but you'll soon improve the point where timing yourself and enemies is second nature, and you'll beat the boss... only to have this cycle repeat itself in the new area you've unlocked. The game has a short and simple tutorial that explains how to play, but you'll have to learn the rest for yourself.Each run of the game gives you a newly generated layout, but between runs you have a sort of hub where you can unlock upgrades (very similar to something like Rogue Legacy), change characters, and train against monsters and bosses. Additionally, there's a daily challenge dungeon available to everyone.Music-wise, each floor of the dungeon has its own BGM. You can set the music to any MP3 you have on your computer (which works very well), but I kept going back to the original music because it's awesome. The default BGM fits the game perfectly.NecroDancer has full controller support, but doesn't really explain it. If you're using a 360 controller like I am, Use (A, B, X, and Y) to move in their respective cardinal directions. This applies to menus too, with B as confirm and X as back. My one qualm with this game so far is this somewhat awkward menu control.Overall, I would highly recommend Crypt of the NecroDancer to anyone. Whether you're a big fan of the genre or just someone looking for a fun title, it has something for you. NecroDancer is definitely worth its price tag.P.S. It's only in alpha and it's already this good It made it out of early accessP.P.S. Do I even need to mention the awesome cheesy pun in the title?P.P.P.S. You can even hook this game up to a USB dance pad, like something you'd use to play Dance Dance Revolution. I don't have one, and even if I did I'm far too lazy / would probably have a heart attack if I tried but STILL. YOU CAN DO THAT.

content:
ry 17, 2016
												One, two, three, four, aah, AAAH, AARGH! ♥♥♥♥!Crypt of the Necrodancer is a beautifully crafted mix between a rhythm game and a tile-based roguelike. You play as one of several characters who are forced to move to the beat of a catchy soundtrack, each with their own quirk to make the game frustrating, painful, and gloriously addictive. Everything can be done using a single set of four context-sensitive buttons. Just press a direction to move, attack, or dig in that direction, and the game will pick the action most conducive to progress. That, of course, doesn't mean you're not going to die. Through the pressure of moving to the beat, you're going to make stupid decisions, and they will be entirely your fault. Every enemy telegraphs their moves and attacks in a predictable pattern, and if you end up cornered by three enemies and your back to a wall, you only have yourself to blame.Every zone has three floors and a boss. The stairs to the next floor are only opened by defeating the miniboss, but you can fall through a trapdoor at the song's end to get to the next floor, if you don't mind the miniboss and several other monsters following you down, forcing you to kill it before you can actually explore the floor.Each boss has their own quirks. King Conga skips the eigth beat, and if you miss a step he'll get off his throne and charge at you. Deep Blues is a literal chessboard, swarming you with pieces that you must clear out before the King stops running away. Coral Riff floods the area, creating water tiles that stop you from moving if you step in them. Death Metal works through several phases at the pace of the fastest song in the game.And, of course, there are the story bosses in the last zone if you're playing as Cadence, Melody, or Aria. Fight the Necrodancer and reclaim your freedom!You can choose to start at any zone after the furthest you've finished, at the cost of not being able to complete more than one zone at a time, or take a top-to-bottom all zones run that starts you with no character upgrades. Completing and exploring individual zones rewards you with diamonds, which allow you to upgrade your character, unlock equipment, spells, and weapons, or buy items to start with in your next zone run.Of course, unlocking items just means you can find them in your next runs! This is a roguelike after all, and every sword, armor, ring, and spell has to be found in the Crypt itself for you to use them.Play as Melody and only attack when moving! Don't get cornered!Play as Eli and blast your enemies to bits... if you don't blow yourself up first!Play as Dove and friendship the monsters away... for a while before they mob you!Play as Monk and find even more ways to die, since you can't touch money!Play as Dorian and realize that moving two spaces at once is more frustrating than helpful!Play as Bolt and learn that double speed is somehow both faster and slower than you expect!Play as Aria and discover that perfect rhythm is even harder when you gotta stay alive too!Play as Bard and move to your own beat... coward.And, once you've done all that, play as Coda, the Monk-Bolt-Aria hybrid. That's all the description you need. Good luck!Overall rating: 4/4 time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Tl:dr; Many games like to try and wear the "easy to learn, hard to master" hat. Crypt of the NecroDancer is one of the titles that wears that hat like a ♥♥♥♥in' champ.Crypt of the NecroDancer is a rythm game. No wait; it's a roguelike. No wait; it's both. It's a procedurally-generated labyrinth in which your actions come in pace with the music. It's an absolutely superlative example of the best Early Access has to offer; oodles of content that's already more than playable, and promising to only get better as time goes on.You play as Cadence, a novice gravedigger (I think; it's not really important) who makes one shovel cut in the wrong place too many. Now your still-beating heart has been stolen. Turns out this isn't as fatal as you'd expect, and it even means you can't die permanently, but it HAS made you a Slave to the Rythm(TM). Can you make it through the NecroDancer's lair in order to kill him and reclaim your heart? Or will you be a slave to the rythm for all eternity?Everything in the NecroDancer's crypts moves and acts to the beat of the music. You can use your own MP3s for this, but the included soundtrack from Danny Baranowsky is so awesome you won't need to. Mastering the beat of the music is the key to victory in this game.Remember when I said Crypt rocks the "easy to learn, hard to master" hat like a boss? This is why. Moving with the beat is one of those things which is very easy to wrap your head around, but mastering the beat is a whole other story. It's a simple concept executed flawlessly, made all the more satisfying by the fact that it makes you angry in the exact right way - with yourself. Harm comes because YOU screwed up. Failure becomes because YOU screwed up. At no point does the game throw anything at you that you can't deal with - or at least, can't learn to deal with it. We can all name dozens of games that are plain broken, where often failure comes because either the game did a whoopsie in its pants or because the random number generator decided it hates your face. Crypt doesn't do that. There's only one thing Crypt will get you angry with; yourself. And that makes it so very compelling. When you fail, you want to do better. You want to get back in there and get further - to wipe away the shame of your earlier failure. Before you know it, you're hooked.Speaking of which... I need to find a new vein so I can get another hit of this delicious juju.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the NecroDancer is a fantastic entry into the Roguelike genre, so let's break it down.The primary draw of the game is the great music and how it is worked into the mechanics. In order to succeed you must move and attack to the beat of the song assigned for the floor. This is both simple and wickedly difficult to keep up, but the better you manage the more gold coins you earn due to a multiplier effect.Stats in most roguelikes depend heavily on luck in finding items or leveling up, but in CotND you can definitely succeed with just the basic starter gear. The reason why is because the game doesn't rely on huge health pools and in fact most monsters can be killed in a single hit and the only monster you MUST kill is the boss on the final floor. Playing conservatively is a very viable tactic because there are many ways to advance to the next floor and there is no leveling up that requires killing monsters.Each dungeon, at least for the moment, is three dane-a-thons of fun and a final boss. So game sessions are short and failure does not leave that typical bitter taste.There's a light quirky sense of humor, especially when the shopkeeper starts belting out tunes with the music. Colors are bright and all the monsters get a little dance-y jig which makes things pretty playful. If you're doing well you also get magical disco lighting all over the dungeon, huzzah!This is the Roguelike for people who like music and a shorter, more meaningful play session. The game itself isn't super long, but the random elements and multiple character types will keep you as busy as you would like.Final Score: A-

It's up to you if you wanna pick this game up for yourself. No regrets.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Necrodancer delivers the electronic beats and a horde of monsters to defeat. Our unlikely herione, Cadance, boldly foregoes the suggested years of dance training and rushes in to save her own heart and vanquish a legendary foe.Roommate 1: "What are you playing, Legend of Zelda?"Roommate 2: "That actually looks like a decent rhythm game."Brace Yourself Games has successfully combined a couple of genres into something you won't expect to be fun into something outright addictive. Every level is randomly generated and challenging in its own right, but there is always a bunch of orderly and easy to learn patterns to every enemy you will encounter. This isn't a game for everyone, but it's a game worth trying despite the fact that it isn't fully developed yet.Sure, the game is a bunch of pixels and the learning curve is a bit harsh. But the satisfaction of beating a single level keeps me coming back for another beating, the default music is awesome, and the game never ceases to be interesting. I don't know if I'll ever get good at it, but it inspires me to no end as a game-designer-in-training. I would regret never having played this game more than I regret a lot of other things.
