21, 2016
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is definitely one of the most unique roguelike games I’ve ever played, with the added bonus of actually resembling rogue instead of using roguelike as another term for “permadeath without saves”.  You play a family of musicians (or a motley crew of side-characters) determined to unlock the mystery of the magical lute and defeat the Necrodancer, a cursed necromantic bard.True to its name, you “dance” around each level by moving in tune to the rhythm meter at the bottom of the screen. Each level has its own tune and rhythm and the game steadily increases the pace as you progress. Keeping in tune with the music while vanquishing enemies will net you a higher multiplier which increases the amount of gold you find, in addition to enhancing certain special items found throughout the crypt. Failing to keep to the beat will cause your multiplier to go down and may also prevent you from moving. Since the monsters in the game also move to the beat, they will eventually close in on you to attack and you cannot stand still to “pause” the action (unless you’re playing the bard character). I found the soundtrack for CotN to be excellent and very diverse. Each level’s song fits its theme pretty well and there are a few tracks that are instantly catchy. The shopkeeper in each level will also sing along with the music, giving a clue to his location, and all of the monsters are either music-themed or have a name alluding to some musical term or instrument, adding an extra layer of detail to this thoroughly polished game.There really aren’t any faults with this game that would prevent any fan of rogues from picking it up (playing as Aria is extremely hard though) and, even if you’re not normally into games in this genre, the learning curve is very fair. This game is worth picking up even at its original cost, though if you can catch it at the average sale price of $5 it’s quite a steal!

er 27, 2015
												I waited to get this game for weeks and I was not disappointed. It's an absolute joy to play, balancing the strategy of roguelikes with the addictiveness of rhythm games. Even though the game itself is short, there's a surprising amount of content with several characters and dozens of items to unlock. Some characters even have their own alternate soundtracks, which constantly keeps the game fresh even after dozens of plays.Really, the only stain marring of this gem is the game's poorly-designed story mode. In order to see all of the game's cutscenes, bosses and songs, one must beat it from start to finish with three specific characters. The first two are fine, but the third is an insane leap in difficulty that requires weeks of practice and an incredible streak of luck to beat.Final verdict: If you pick up this game, expect to have a good time while it lasts. Try out all the characters, pick up some mods, get some achievements, but don't expect that you'll be able to finish it.

content:
er 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'll admit, I was a bit skeptical of this game when I first started.  I loved DDR and I love roguelikes, but to mix the two?  What fresh madness was this?  THIS WAS THE EPIC MUSIC MADNESS OF THE DEEP!  The music is energetic and fun, the game is easy to learn and the tutorial is short (seriously, VERY short, but all you need to know).The game is most certainly a roguelike, no saves, randomized layouts and drops.  But that's just the beginning.  Your ability to sync your movements to the beat isn't just a gimmick.  This mechanic rewards you with things like coin bonuses for the long combos you can create as you dance through the levels.  It requires you to plan while you move, if you stop, you miss a beat and you lose your combo.  The game is simple and addicting.  You never feel too bad about dying because you use the rewards you gained from the previous play to help you on your next, simply perpetuating your endless jimmy through the dark tunnels as you slay monsters with  your dance moves and your beat only legend can recount.A bit pricey at $15.  I bought it on sale and it was well worth the money.  If you love roguelikes and love awesome soundtracks, it could very well be worth the money.  If you're on the fence, wait for a sale and jump on the deal like Jon Travolta on a disco beat.

content:
ry 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the Necrodancer is the game where you think you're good at beating down monsters to the beat... then you unlock hardcore mode. You think of this as impossible as Zone 3 is one giant zerg rush of skeleton horses and elemental enemies. Nonetheless you try it anyway and manage to get some decent gear. Then a red dragon comes along and says "♥♥♥♥ you!" and you get one shot by a fireball because you can't do the sacred red dragon dance at that moment. (That's my life, i cri evertim ;;) But seriously, this game is amazing in many aspects. It's hard to find a game where a particular character dies from picking up GOLD, of all things! Since the levels are randomly generated there is no true pattern to the game and permanent death is indeed a thing. So that guy that dies from picking up gold? He's no exception, better watch your step! Oh yeah, and the only way you can move/attack/dig/open chests is by hitting the arrow key in the direction that you want to go on the beat of the song that's playing. There's a nice little tutorial in-game for that, though. However, there is one thing that bugs me about Crypt of the Necrodancer. That is, the diamonds that are used to purchase items to be put into the item pool for non-hardcore runs. It would make more sense to have everything unlocked already, like hardcore does, but you are forced to buy it using diamonds you find during non-hardcore runs. It's a bit more harmful than helpful and everything should just be unlocked for you to use when it's found. Despite that, this game is well worth your time. I've got 60+ hours and counting clocked into Crypt of the Necrodancer and it's not like I'll be stopping anytime soon. If you like challenging games, get this game. If you like rogue-likes, get this game. If you like rhythm based games, get this game. The point is, just buy the freaking game! What're you waiting for? Scroll back up and click that "Add to cart" button!

28, 2015
												For the rogue-like and rhythm fans alike, this game provides an amazing soundtrack, lots of replay ability with its randomly generated levels, items, and bosses, as well as amazing pixel art! If you don't have this game, buy it now, it's worth every penny! (And for the people who are a bit tight when it comes to pecuniary measures, don't worry, this game has been on sale a lot these past few days!) I'd recommend this to any friend or family member who wants to have a great, grooving time! I'm extremely glad I can be a part of this community too. I honestly need to start a real life group that's filled with people who love the game as much as I do, because Crypt of the NecroDancer is one of my favorite games due to the amount of detail the sound crew, pixel artists, and everyone else had done (I also have to thank the person who made the puns for everyone of the enemy names personally, they're amazing without a doubt)! Although I only have around 50 hours of playing the game, you can bet on the shopkeeper's amazing voice that you'll love it too. And if the wide variety of characters, weapons, etc. aren't enough for you, you can even download mods! A personal favorite of my being the Captain Falcon reskins with sound, truly amazing.) With a great community and even greater team, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a must have. And now, after the real review is over, I must now make a musical pun to balance out the silliness (and to show respect for the beautiful, beautiful man/woman/team who came up with the puns.). Let's see... oh, I have one! If you do not like this game for whatever reason, then you can kindly and respectfully kiss my brass! Heh, I don't mean to toot my own horn or anything, but musical puns are the 'key' to success! (But back to seriousness, 10 out of 10, would recommend to everyone who plays video games and/or loves music.)

content:
er 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Another day, another roguelike. This one has a very unique and downright fun mechanic - move to the music! Every move you make, every attack you make, needs to be on time with the (very well done, and very enjoyable) background track. Stay on beat and get more money to buy upgrades, miss beats, get attacked and probably get dead.Watch the intro video for a quick idea of how this works.Gamewise, this is your average roguelike dungeon crawler. It is fun, and the music mechanic is enough to carry the game through its few shortfalls, Bear in mind that this is early access and there is a decent amount of missing content. Many upgrades are not available, and one entire dungeon did not exist at time of writing.Recommend steering clear of the the "add your own music" feature, because frankly, it's crap. Beats continuing through silence, they're not detected accurately, and so on. The pack-in tracks are good enough that you won't want to do this anyways.That said, those minor issues aside, I really recommend this game in spite of the unfinished-ness. If this game is this good at this stage in its development, really, it can only get better. Thumbs up!

												Let me just say, I didn't really know what I was getting into when I first bought the game. I thought "oh, it's just going to be a fun little rythem game that I could easily beat". I was so wrong. It was a game that was easy to learn and hard to master. The first zone was actually more difficult then I expected, but I beat it without troble. By the time zone 3 came, I was just about to throw my controller. But, I kept going, kept persisting and eventually I beat all of the zones. But, the replability comes in with new characters with differnt atributes that kept me coming back to play again. This game is harder then I thought, but it was definitly worth my money.Pros:-Fun, simple rythem game.-Ability to use custom music. (Just hearing Weird Al sing Bukingham Blues on the Deep Blues boss was sooooooooooooooo satisfying.)-Tons of differnt characters to unlock.-All zones mode to dare the experanced players.-Clean, pixel graphics.-Awsome music. (There are three versions too!)Cons:-Needs more weapons/items to unlock, I basicly got them all once I reached zone 3 with my first character.-Needs an online co-op (Local feels like multiplayer in the 90's)-Needs a better interface on the level creator. (I found it slightly annoying actually, you have to use the arrow keys, enter and delete and it quickly got tedious.)Overall I give this game 9/10. I had a lot of fun with it and it has the potential to pack in a ton more hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 29, 2014
												Crypt of the NecroDancer is a dungeon - crawler with rogue - like elements... Yeah, I know. Go ahead. Sigh if you want to. It's okay. I'll wait. Yes, it's true. We're currently in a market hugely oversaturated with "dungeon-crawling roguelike" titles. But unlike many other games of its genre, NecroDancer manages to stand out and hold its own with its unique and very fun spin on the familiar idea.The premise is simple enough. You enter the first floor of a procedurally-generated dungeon, moving in four cardinal directions, fighting various monsters and finding random treasure items such as weapons, armor, spells and consumables. On each floor of the dungeon there's a shopkeeper you can do business with.Sounds very familiar, right? Well this is where NecroDancer does things differently. Everything you do in the dungeon, such as moving, fighting, using items, and digging through walls... you have to synchronize with the beat of the music. All of the enemies follow this rule too, and as a result you have a system that's fairly easy to pick up and very satisfying to master and tinker with. On your first few runs you'll be so concerned with keeping the beat that you'll just throw yourself headfirst into enemies and traps, but you'll soon improve the point where timing yourself and enemies is second nature, and you'll beat the boss... only to have this cycle repeat itself in the new area you've unlocked. The game has a short and simple tutorial that explains how to play, but you'll have to learn the rest for yourself.Each run of the game gives you a newly generated layout, but between runs you have a sort of hub where you can unlock upgrades (very similar to something like Rogue Legacy), change characters, and train against monsters and bosses. Additionally, there's a daily challenge dungeon available to everyone.Music-wise, each floor of the dungeon has its own BGM. You can set the music to any MP3 you have on your computer (which works very well), but I kept going back to the original music because it's awesome. The default BGM fits the game perfectly.NecroDancer has full controller support, but doesn't really explain it. If you're using a 360 controller like I am, Use (A, B, X, and Y) to move in their respective cardinal directions. This applies to menus too, with B as confirm and X as back. My one qualm with this game so far is this somewhat awkward menu control.Overall, I would highly recommend Crypt of the NecroDancer to anyone. Whether you're a big fan of the genre or just someone looking for a fun title, it has something for you. NecroDancer is definitely worth its price tag.P.S. It's only in alpha and it's already this good It made it out of early accessP.P.S. Do I even need to mention the awesome cheesy pun in the title?P.P.P.S. You can even hook this game up to a USB dance pad, like something you'd use to play Dance Dance Revolution. I don't have one, and even if I did I'm far too lazy / would probably have a heart attack if I tried but STILL. YOU CAN DO THAT.

content:
8, 2016
 Crypt of the NecroDancer review 	After 200 hours of playtime I think it is finally the time to do a review of Crypt of the NecroDancer... so lets get startedCrypt of the NecroDancer is a Rythm based Rouge-like, so If you like the awesome soundtrack and don`t mind restarting from the beginning, then this would be the perfect game for you.+Great Soundtrack by DannyB (Also did music for Meatboy etc.), A_Rival and FamilyJules7x+Graphics - They fit the game really good (Dancing skeletons too)+Easy contols (You only have to use 4 arrow keys, but you can bind the button combos to other buttons too)+Contoller/Dancepad support+Highly skill based (You can beat the game without picking up any items)+Awesome Shopkeeper+++ Finally beating that boss you never beaten before-Getting into the game, as you have to learn the enemy pattern, get into the beat etc.Crypt of the Necrodancer gets a solid 9.5/10 from me :Pbtw... only game you can play with 1 hand  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

content:
25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Oh this game. Simple, difficult, and incredibly addictive. Even in it's incomplete form I have been pouring hours in every day. Necrodancer's art style is charming and beautiful, the soundtrack is earwormy and wonderful, and the gameplay is tough as nails but fair. Play through each zone seperately and aquire gems to unlock new equipment and expand your health or magic, and then attempt Hardcore Mode where the game really begins. Completion of hardcore modes takes skill and concentration, but the feeling of actually doing well at it is quite rewarding. Unlike many other roguelikes, this game is NOT gear dependant. You CAN beat it with nothing but the starting equipment. It's just extremely hard. My only complaint at this point is I WANT MORE STUFF. EXPAND EXPAND EXPAND! |hugs game|

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 7, 2016
												With the surge in popularity of roguelikes, it was an eventuality that developers would need to do something other than merely make another punishing dungeon crawler like the original Rogue. While there have been many grand takes on the formula by entrants like Rogue Legacy, FTL, and Nuclear Throne, the last concept I was expecting was a roguelike crossed with a rhythm game. I wondered how this mashup would even work, but it turned out that the answer was quite simple; you just press the arrow keys in time with the music’s beat while traversing floors of a dungeon. Simple premise, but Necrodancer is deviously challenging because of its rhythmical movement, even if it can suffer from incredible roguelike luck.Dance Dance Revolution meets a dungeon crawler is the quickest and easiest way to define the game. Both the enemies and your movements are tied to the music’s beat, where trying to move on an offbeat will result in an awkward hop in place, and skipping a beat will act as a ‘passed turn’, both dropping your combo. Most enemies have a specific pattern or interaction with the beat, like how skeletons will raise their arms for one beat before moving forward on the following one, or how minotaurs will charge in a straight rhythmic line upon direct sight. Learning these patterns and quirks will let you dance around enemies, and pulling out deft, tactical evasions of enemy mobs never fails to be incredibly satisfying. Items and equipment are available to be discovered or purchased (via a rather vocal and potentially homicidal shopkeeper), including weaponry like longswords that supply an extra square of attack range, boots that let you walk across hazards without a care, rings that bestow various effects like increasing the amount of gold dropped by enemies, spectacles that will let you see what treasure you’ll get from chests and other containers, and other fun utilities. Some loadouts of equipment are more preferable than others, and gathering them becomes a priority in order to make later sections laughably easy. No need to worry about lava or ice when you can just float above the floor! No need to worry about health when you have a blood bow that lets you kill enemies from afar and replenish your health! There are trade-offs between items and gear of course and your ‘this is the run’ loadout will no doubt vary from my own, but once you get an optimal loadout, the game’s later challenging sections become trivial save for boss fights. On the flip side, poor luck resulting in less than ideal loadouts can also occur, and raw player skill can only go so far in some cases.The challenge in Necrodancer primarily comes from how the enemies never -ever- falter in their timing and movements with the music; The player however can (and will, on your first few attempts) make mistakes, thus making a missed beat punishing or potentially run-ending - Not to mention you lose your gold multiplier from being struck by an enemy. Many roguelikes require situational and environmental awareness in order to avoid losing a run, but Necrodancer demands auditory awareness on top of it all, what with how the music is your means of moving. Thankfully the developers included a visual aid of a heart that beats with every beat, as well as scales that close in on the heart to cue you on when movement or attacking is possible, which is both kind and intelligent on their part. I cannot list the number of times I’ve panicked and had to look at the heart beat in order to get back on rhythm. The music doesn’t last forever however, and if you’re still on the dungeon floor before the song ends and you don’t reach the exit, you’ll automatically be ejected to the next floor. Also as a kind gesture there’s a bestiary that lets you practice against encountered enemies to study their patterns and traits - Considering the later difficulty, these aids help balance the field. Necrodancer had more characters and modes of play added during its period in early access, like dance mat support, a cooperative mode, and even a custom track function to let you jive around dungeon floors with your own music. The core game doesn’t really change, it simply becomes modified with the various characters and different rules. There’s even a puzzle mode that gives you a floor to tackle using specific items and strategies that quickly becomes head scratching, and of course included is a daily seed that gives all players the same dungeon to take on and go for a high score. Once you get a solid grasp of the game and can get successful runs frequently, these various ways to play improve the longevity of a game that would’ve otherwise been rather short and easy to gleam over.Your purchase for Crypt of the Necrodancer will primarily rely on whether or not you enjoy the soundtrack; if you don’t, chances are you’re not going to have a good time. Rhythm games can only be so enjoyable if the soundtrack doesn’t sit well with the player, and in my case I’m a fan for most of Necrodancer’s tracks. Danny Baranowsky’s composition is full, vibrant and seldom with any musical downtime, which lends a very active listening experience to the game; for a game where the combat and movement is based on musical beats, having any song be boring or lacking instrumentation would result in dull gameplay. The backing synth for many of the tracks end up giving the soundtrack an almost gothic/horror feel but doing so within its techno/rocking manner. Of course, that’s when you discover later on that there are not one but -two- remixed soundtracks in later sections of the story mode, with the first striking chords of a laser disco and the second more grounded in reality with heavier, nastier rock. All three soundtracks have been uploaded to YouTube if you want to judge for yourself, which is advisable homework when it comes to purchasing rhythm games.Necrodancer’s strengths lie in its longevity, challenge and gimmick; like many roguelikes the difficulty does become somewhat trivial once you are knowledgeable of its components and mechanics. That said, the demands the game makes of the player ensures that you can know what items work well together and can dance around enemy patterns easily, but it all means nothing if you can’t execute tactfully. Back up this challenge with fantastic music and multiple ways to play, and you get a roguelike that is both satisfying and incredibly enjoyable.

content:
y 6, 2015
												You buy it now! I mean it.This is a concept game, and an incredibly good idea!Four keys are required to play, the arrows, nothing else. And with these four keys, you will "dance" on the music toward victory! or a quick death... Every step you take is a move, an attack, or a special action. On a slow music, you have about one move per second, a lots of time to think and make the best choice... but on a fast music, your reflexes will be challenged because the smallest error can kill you.The game offers many different items, all offering different advantages. The strategical value here is to know when to buy or not an item depending on your situation. Every game feels different with the random dungeons and you will never get bored playing.The game also displays many different monsters, all with a unique AI. Some are easy, you will love them; some are nasty, and you will hate them. The game doesn't force you to kill all ennemies of course, only one : the boss... but killing ennemies give you gold, and gold give you better objects. You will have to decide all the time if you risk it or not... quick! You have one music beat to decide! Oh too late... :)

content:
r 20, 2016
												A roguelike (i.e. a turn based game where you explore a dungeon, with a different layout every game, finding loot and slaying monsters), with the turns set to a musical beat. NecroDancer negates most of the genre's traditional flaws.NecroDancer has adorable pixel art in a style reminiscent of the good 2D Legend of Zelda games, but more colourful. Roguelikes traditionally have either ASCII art or crappy looking tiles.NecroDancer is fast paced and games typically last no more than 30 minutes. Roguelikes traditionally take hours to play.NecroDancer has wonderful music and sounds. Roguelikes traditionally have either nonexistent or very bad music and sound effects.NecroDancer has simple, predictable rules for enemies (albeit challenging because you have to act on them fast). Roguelikes traditionally make the dungeon monsters all behave erratically.NecroDancer has simple controls. You play with literally just the arrow keys, occasionally pressing 2 arrows together. Traditional roguelikes such as NetHack not only have a different action for every single character A through Z both with and without the shift key, but also have an "extended" set of commands that you have to type by name to use, because there just aren't enough keys on a keyboard for them.The main downside is that NecroDancer is really difficult to play if you have a massive hangover like I do right now. Traditional roguelikes are no more punishingly difficult than usual when you can barely see the screen and have to stare at each individual inch with one eye, because you can just take as long as you need to pray at the porcelain throne in between turns.

content:
5, 2014
Early Access Review
								As i am writing this please keep in mind this is from the early alpha build so there may be many things yet to be added into the game in the near future.This game is a really good mix of rhythm meets rouge-like rpg, when you begin you have little on you and can only move when the beat hits the sweet spot (or something like that), and as you go deeper into the Crypt, or zones (whatever you prefer), you will meet stronger monsters and newer upgrades, all of which have a unique take of gameplay. Please also note that you will die a few times on your first try but thats ok, when you die you have a chance to spend any gathered diamonds on upgrades or extra items found in chests and then try again. The Crypts/zones are always randomised meaning not every run will be the same, some will be easy as in the exit is right in front of you, other times you would need to fight through a mini-army to exit the place and will bring many challenges for you to face. At the end of each Crypt/zone, ussually on the forth floor, you will face one of three bosses, all of which brings an interesting take to battle.And if you get board with the in-game soundtrack (no idea why since the merchants singing is quite fun) you can always add your own music and try get through with your own beats.So far the alpha has three Crypts/zones with the forth in the making still, but what i've seen the game is really good and i would recommend this game to anyone for how fun its turned out to be.Personally i give this game a 9/10 (c^_^c)

content:
er 17, 2015
												This game, just by hearing the type that it is, causes most people to doubt it or wrinkle their nose in confusion. You'd probably think that at first too, it's a dungeon crawler, a rhythm game, and a totally amazing rogue-like game. How does it work? We may never know, but one thing's for certain: a game of this difficulty that's this fun to play deserves more recognition. Like, a lot more. The soundtracks, all three of them, all provide something awesome to the game. I've only had it for a couple days now (yeah, I'm that guy who shows up three hours into the party and acts all cool about it) but that doesn't mean I don't know that this is a game far beyond amazing. Cheers to everyone at Brace Yourself Games, you've created a masterpiece of a game that lots of people will agree is easily one of the best rhythm games out there. I'd go on, but there are too many things that are awesome about this game that I'd probably end up breaking the character limit or something. Don't worry Rhythm Heaven, you've always got a special place in my heartBut seriously, get this game. It's more than worth the $15, no doubt about it.

content:
29, 2015
												If you haven't bought this already, buy it.Pros: The dungeons are different every time.Tons of characters with very different playstyles (ex the default character has to move to the beat, another one can move to his own beat, one more has infinite bombs, etc.)The music will get you. I literally cannot get the music out of my head.Pretty easy to understand. You only use the arrow keys.Daily Challenge (if that's your thing). Every day a random dungeon is set up and you get one run to score as high as possible. There's a global leaderboard.Pop in your own music and play to its beats.Cons:If you don't like rhythm games, well you won't like this. It is very VERY hard at first. You meet lots of enemies who each have their own movement and attack patterns. You will probably die a lot, and it can be frustrating. There are a lot of items that can make the game either a (relative) breeze or very hard if you don't have them.I don't really know if it's a con or not, but it was frustrating.End of list.TL;DRThis is my GOTY.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2016
												BUY/SALE/PASS: Buy - Feel free to buy at full price.Crypt of the Necrodancer is a rhythm roguelike dungeon crawler action RPG from developer Brace Yourself Games and publisher Klei Entertainment, and if the description of the game is confusing, don’t worry.  So is the game.  Players are dropped into randomly generated dungeons and tasked to explore as deep as possible without dying.  Death is permanent; when you die, you start from the beginning all over again.Exploring, fighting, looting, moving, everything is played to the beat of the Danny Baranowsky chiptune soundtrack.  You are likely to die many, many times as you come to learn the various kinds of loot you’ll find and the multitude of enemies to fight.  The good news is that the game is ultimately fun to play and enjoy for players who are into rhythm games and randomized dungeons; the bad news is that getting to that point is layered underneath the frustration of not knowing what to do for the first few hours.  Stick with it long enough, and this game becomes really engrossing to play.

content:
13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is phenomenal. It gives a full roguelike experience but with a unique twist - all movement and actions must be done in sync with the background music. It really is, in effect, a cross between a classic roguelike and a rhythm game such as DDR or osu!This is more than just a gameplay gimmick. The entire game relies deliberate consistent movement and fast thinking. All enemies have very predictable attack patterns but that hardly makes the game easy. When you have to contend with several different enemies and traps on the screen at once the difficulty can get very challenging, especially in the later levels.Like all roguelikes, you, as a player, get exponentially better with game experience and knowledge. At first even the earliest floors of the dungeon may seem impossible, but as you start getting faster at processing your situation and taking advantage of your resources, you're able to delve deeper and deeper into the crypt with less effort. Eventually you may find even the nastiest enemies have no chance against your well timed steps. The skill ceiling is so high it's actually possible to beat all consecutive areas without taking damage using the starting weapon. In fact, there is a character and achievement for doing just this.The best part is that it's all just so satisfying. Not only does everything about this game feel well thought out and balanced, it's hard to express just how good it feels to take all of your actions in time with the music. Every living (or unliving) thing in the dungeon is literally dancing or bobbing its head in sync with the rhythm and it's all just so.. fun! Did I mention the soundtrack is awesome? The soundtrack is awesome.

												No game has had songs looping through my head quite like this one.  The game was a lot of fun as well, definitely play with a controller.  It reminded me of Rogue Legacy in that when you start out you'll probably die quite a bit, then as you go you'll both unlock items to help you get better and you'll learn tricks on helping yourself. content:
2, 2016
												I got this game a few months ago and it is really fun to play!The reason I keep coming back to this game are these reasons:   -Great soundtrack   -Decent story (after finishing the first character, Cadence)   -Great gameplay   -Isn't a game you will beat in a week or two   -5 different soundtracks   -Support for custom music   -Mod support (texture mods and music replacements)   -Level editor (You need to beat the game with one character first)That all may sound great, but this game is NOT for everyone!  This game requires a lot of patience and practice.  It's fairly straight forward to play, but extremely hard to master.  The game requires you to beat each zone (individually at least) without missing a beat of the song and perfect movements.  If you cannot keep tempo/rhythm, this will not be a game for you.  The game heavily relies on you to be able to keep up with fast tempos.  If you can't do that, this game may not be for you! This game, however could be good for you if you do want to practice keeping tempo.I would rate this game 9/10 for being ridiculously fun, but a bit infuriating when trying to beat the game with a harder character (like Aria or the monk)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2016
												Brace Yourself Games has developed easily one of the most creative games I've played recently.  Crypt of the Necrodancer combines the roguelike/rhythm genres to produce a dungeon crawler that summons memories of Michael Jackson's Thriller. The skeletons dance, the zombies hop, and the shopkeepers sing as you navigate through the floors of the cryptIt plays similarly to classic turn based style roguelikes, except that the turns happen on the beat of the music.  You will find yourself hopping back and forth to the beat, dodging enemy attacks, and waiting for the perfect moment to strike.  The soundtrack is great, but you can play using your own music instead if you wish.  There is also an easier difficulty setting specifically for playing the game on a dance pad.  It makes me wish I still had a DDR pad lying around, I'd love to give it a try.The parallels with classic roguelikes do not end with the turn based combat/movement system.  The floors, the contents of treasure chests, shop items, and even boss order are all randomly generated.  The game is also very challenging, quite possibly challenging enough that some players won't enjoy it if they don't like difficult games.  There are several features available to the player to mitigate the challenge.  As you play you will unlock the ability to start at each zone, buy items before entering a zone, and practice against enemies in a risk free environment.The only criticism that comes to mind about the game is the small number of zones.  There are four zones, and each zone has three stages.  The amount of content reminds me of some NES games.  Many old NES titles could be completed in less than an hour, but took much longer due to the learning required to play successfully.  While I don't feel like there are as many zones as there could have been, they did include ten playable characters.  The characters all have very different styles of play and allow for a solid level of replay value.Crypt of the Necrodancer is a lot of fun, but I think many players should be wary.  Prospective buyers may be lured in by the cute visuals and awesome soundtrack but miss an important fact about the game.  Necrodancer, at its heart, is a challenging turn based roguelike.  I've played through and finished quite a few games that most would consider to be hard.  This one is tough.  According to  Steam's global gameplay stats, 7.2% of players manage to finish the fourth zone as the main character.  If you're down for a challenge though, you'll have a great time.  I've certainly had a lot of fun with it.

content:
, 2015
												Crypt of the Necrodancer's a really inventive game. It takes two things that don't really go together--rhythm and dungeon crawling--and mixes them so beautifully. Playing a game like this to the rhythm of music makes it incredibly easy to get into a certain flow. Combat is smooth and challenging. The sound design and OST are phenomenal and really add to the overall atmosphere of the game. Having been keeping track of the game since early in its Early Access days, I was satisfied with the product back then and am even more so satisfied with it now. Crypt of the Necrodancer is truly worth all fifteen dollars you pay for it. I could not recommend this game more.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
r 28, 2016
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is a dungeon-crawler, rouge-like, rythm RPG with loot. You can only move and attack monsters along with the beat of the song playing, so you have to memorize the pattern of each monster's movements and attacks to kill them. It's not as hard as I made it sound, but can still be fairly difficult. If it gets too hard, which isn't likely, you can go into a training zone of the monster you struggle to defeat.Moving and attacking with the beat isn't hard, and deploying weapons and attacks you've aqcuired just takes a combo of two arrow keys.The story of the game is nothing special, and that's completely fine. The replayability is beautiful, and there is also a daily challenge to keep you playing.What I love about this game the most is that although it's hard, I've never rage quit. The fun outweighs the difficulty to keep you playing. You can add custom music from your computer's files, but it will disable achievements.It's a beautiful game with a great soundtrack, achievements, and Steam Workshop support to change the textures (Undertale, Megaman ect.) If you like retro RPGs and rythm based games, it's for you.

I've only had it for a couple days now (yeah, I'm that guy who shows up three hours into the party and acts all cool about it) but that doesn't mean I don't know that this is a game far beyond amazing. Cheers to everyone at Brace Yourself Games, you've created a masterpiece of a game that lots of people will agree is easily one of the best rhythm games out there. I'd go on, but there are too many things that are awesome about this game that I'd probably end up breaking the character limit or something. Don't worry Rhythm Heaven, you've always got a special place in my heartBut seriously, get this game. It's more than worth the $15, no doubt about it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2016
												Brace Yourself Games has developed easily one of the most creative games I've played recently.  Crypt of the Necrodancer combines the roguelike/rhythm genres to produce a dungeon crawler that summons memories of Michael Jackson's Thriller. The skeletons dance, the zombies hop, and the shopkeepers sing as you navigate through the floors of the cryptIt plays similarly to classic turn based style roguelikes, except that the turns happen on the beat of the music.  You will find yourself hopping back and forth to the beat, dodging enemy attacks, and waiting for the perfect moment to strike.  The soundtrack is great, but you can play using your own music instead if you wish.  There is also an easier difficulty setting specifically for playing the game on a dance pad.  It makes me wish I still had a DDR pad lying around, I'd love to give it a try.The parallels with classic roguelikes do not end with the turn based combat/movement system.  The floors, the contents of treasure chests, shop items, and even boss order are all randomly generated.  The game is also very challenging, quite possibly challenging enough that some players won't enjoy it if they don't like difficult games.  There are several features available to the player to mitigate the challenge.  As you play you will unlock the ability to start at each zone, buy items before entering a zone, and practice against enemies in a risk free environment.The only criticism that comes to mind about the game is the small number of zones.  There are four zones, and each zone has three stages.  The amount of content reminds me of some NES games.  Many old NES titles could be completed in less than an hour, but took much longer due to the learning required to play successfully.  While I don't feel like there are as many zones as there could have been, they did include ten playable characters.  The characters all have very different styles of play and allow for a solid level of replay value.Crypt of the Necrodancer is a lot of fun, but I think many players should be wary.  Prospective buyers may be lured in by the cute visuals and awesome soundtrack but miss an important fact about the game.  Necrodancer, at its heart, is a challenging turn based roguelike.  I've played through and finished quite a few games that most would consider to be hard.  This one is tough.  According to  Steam's global gameplay stats, 7.2% of players manage to finish the fourth zone as the main character.  If you're down for a challenge though, you'll have a great time.  I've certainly had a lot of fun with it.

												I got this game a few months ago and it is really fun to play!The reason I keep coming back to this game are these reasons:   -Great soundtrack   -Decent story (after finishing the first character, Cadence)   -Great gameplay   -Isn't a game you will beat in a week or two   -5 different soundtracks   -Support for custom music   -Mod support (texture mods and music replacements)   -Level editor (You need to beat the game with one character first)That all may sound great, but this game is NOT for everyone!  This game requires a lot of patience and practice.  It's fairly straight forward to play, but extremely hard to master.  The game requires you to beat each zone (individually at least) without missing a beat of the song and perfect movements.  If you cannot keep tempo/rhythm, this will not be a game for you.  The game heavily relies on you to be able to keep up with fast tempos.  If you can't do that, this game may not be for you! This game, however could be good for you if you do want to practice keeping tempo.I would rate this game 9/10 for being ridiculously fun, but a bit infuriating when trying to beat the game with a harder character (like Aria or the monk)

content:
, 2015
												Ever wanted to play Dance Dance Revolution but with a bit of action and narrative added to the mix? Well Crypt of the Necrodancer is a good waltz in the right direction! Crypt of the Necrodancer is a rhythm, rogue-like dungeon crawler that has you moving and attacking to the beat of the tune.The gameplay as stated above generally has you doing everything to the beat of the tune by using only the arrow keys, whether your in the main lobby or fighting your way through the next level. You can even set the game up to be played with a dance pad! In the main lobby you're able to buy permanent upgrades to weapons, armor, spells and trinkets found in the levels,  practice against certain enemies, read background about the game and choose which zones you'll be "dancing" through along with a few other options. In the zones themselves the overall objective is to find the stairwell to the next level, however that doesn't necessarily mean you should be racing for the stairwell with all due haste. Diamonds, your currency for permanent upgrades, can only be found while exploring these levels, and once you are done with a zone you will only have those diamonds in your next trip to the lobby. Once you decide to go back into a zone you will lose all the diamonds you collected on the previous trip! So finding enough diamonds to buy those ever increasingly costing upgrades can be well worth the exploration. Remember how I said those permanent upgrades to items only affect what you find in the levels and are not given to the characters themselves? Those items can either be found throughout said levels or in the shop in each level. Enemies drop gold in order for you to purchase these items from the store, and if you keep up with the beat, a coin multiplier is added when you kill enemies so you get more gold for your kills. With that being said the levels are on a time limit, can you guess what that time limit is? The music! If the music you are playing to finishes before you get to the stairs you are immediately dropped to the next level. On top of this each level has a boss, and not only will you lose your multiplier combo if the song ends but rather than being dropped into a relatively safe room at the beginning of the next level you will have to face that levels boss immediately if the previous levels boss wasn't defeated. The games uses pixel art and uses it's musical theme in some of the enemy designs. For example the Minotaur enemy's  horns are actually a harp and the reaper has a microphone attached to his scythe. This leads to a very visually pleasing themed art style that looks and plays it's part.The music is electronic and catchy, even making you want to stay on a level just to keep listening. In lower levels of each zone the beat is actually slower so that players adjust to the beat as it get faster with each level.Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fun and enchanting game and is well worth your time and if you have a love for rhythm and rogue-like games alike, this original gem will not disappoint you.

Early Access Review
								Addictive, catchy, hard. I feel a "puzzle game" vibe from some of the things you have to do in this game.The ability to quickly restart a run makes this game incredibly difficult to stop playing, and the sound blending between the Hot and Cold area themes in Zone 3 makes it so that particular music never gets old, even as I try for the 50th time to beat the flipping first stage...Due to the amount of enemies you have to rapidly and strategically dispose of at some points, I feel like mastering this game will take me quite some time. That's a good thing in this case, because it's all due to simple concepts blending together to make something challenging. You know where you went wrong and why you died, and if you didn't, the deathcam is very helpful in pointing that out.The majority of the upgrades could probably do with some sort of price increase. I had no issue unlocking pretty much all of them pretty quickly, before I had even a chance to use 80% of them, and stat keeping would be cool too, but these are just balance suggestions rather than complaints and they barely put a scratch on the rock solid game that is CotN.

content:
r 11, 2015
												I've been addicted to this game since I started playing it. I am not a big fan of rogue-likes in general, but this game is among few rare exceptions.You have 4 zones to beat, each one contains 3 floors and a boss fight. Every zone has its own theme and enemies. But wait, there's more. The enemies each move to the beat in their own unique pattern, and you have to recognize it and adapt quickly. For example, some enemies might be moving along a scripted path, others try to go for you specifically, some might stay still for 2 beats and then move on the 3rd one, others might move on every beat, and so on. It's all very well done.During your dungeon crawling, you'll also come across a lot of items of varying degrees of helpfulness. You have healing items, weapons, armour, rings, spells, and even some unusual items. Some can spawn from the start, others require unlocking via collectible diamonds. You can even remove the less useful items from the dungeons via the janitor, so that there's more chances instead for chests to contain the items you find more useful.There is of course a fair bit of luck involved, as is pretty common with rogue-like games. At times you'll be lucky to find a nice weapon and other useful items early on, other times you'll just be spawning with enemies all around you. It is a very challenging game. You will die a lot. But you do learn to recognize the enemy movement patterns and eventually overcome them.I also really like the whole light-hearted theme the game is going for. I think the devs pulled it off perfectly. The music is also amazing and will just drag you in to the beat.In addition to the regular mode with the main character, you also get to unlock several other characters, which seem to have their own unique abilities (for example one of them can only confuse enemies but not kill, another is only able to use bombs, and so on). It all adds an extra challenge for those who want it. You can even go and practice fighting against specific enemies and bosses if you wish.Great game in general. Highly recommended.

								I might not have played this game that much, but I am absolutely in love with it. This game provides a fun and challenging experience for all players to enjoy. From the combat and movement system, to the wonderful and energetic music, this game is amazing, while not perfect, as it is in early alpha, it still keeps me entertained. Every enemy has a pattern to it, which means you need to memorize it to do good, there is no RNG nonsense. In the game you move and attack to a beat. Once you break the beat, or you lose your coin multiplier (for cadence at least, not sure about the other characters) which can make the game a lot harder on you. If you can keep a beat this game is for you. All in all I give it a 9/10 at the moment, rating subject to change as more updates come out.

Early Access Review
								As a rogue-like fan, I must admit that this game is really good despite being an early access game because you can't solely rely on your luck but you also really need to have the skills to complete a level.Pro(s): - Good gameplay by combining rhythm with dungeon crawler- Good design with cute pixel art graphics- High replayability because you can play with different modes and use different characters- An awesome soundtrack by Danny Baranowsky (I really enjoyed the music)- And a little bit tricky (like destroying walls with bomb to get a lot of money :P)Con(s):- The content is still not that much right now because it's still an early access but the workshop content from the community can fill the gap- The shortcut/hotkey for the items and spells is hard to be pressed using keyboard maybe it's different when using gamepad or dance pad since I don't have both- The enemies have fixed pattern and that makes the enemies predictable maybe the enemies need to have combination of patterns to make it unpredictableI highly recommend this game because it's challenging and fun and it has awesome soundtrack, you really need to buy the soundtrack as well

You might think that this just happened because your boss is an ♥♥♥ and while that part is also true, it's not the only truth behind it.In fact, he is afraid and he has to be afraid, because Crypt of the FreedomDancer is a lot more than just some indie book around music, it's actually a political concept that might open your eyes behind what you do and it might end up with you standing up, defending your democratic rights and take back what the sinister communist boss of yours took away from you a long time ago.Crypt of the LibertyDancer, or FREEDOM in short, is a political RTS shooting firefighter simulation in which you take the role of a supressed American worker that is enslaved by the liberal agenda of communists like Obama and Clinton. You have to dance in the rhythm that they dictate without congress approval and while doing that, you are trying to dismantle the system of injustice and slavery that they built up.Level by level you accomplish that by destroying their supression machine in form of evil monsters, skeletons and spiders that come down from your wall. You kill every brainwashed liberal boss in the end of each world and end up in the hort of evil itself, the bureau of Hillary Clinton him very self.Of course, he is entirely invulnerable until you take a guitar named Donald Trump to hit him, then he becomes vulnerable and you can kill him. Once you accomplished that, America is once again free of a dictated rhythm and you can proceed in your life in peace, wealth and prosperity.The symbolism here is clearly political and obvious. You are the great hero that is to dismantle the sinister machine of doom the liberals created, however you have to follow the rules they dictated in order to prevail.How is that fair you ask? Well, it isn't. That's what liberals are about. Being unfair and evil.In order to fully grasp the vastness that this game covers politically, we should take a look into the founding of Israel after World War II in 1473. The United States of America that just created the greatest and most freedom-loving army in world history and in order to re-establish fairness and peace over the world, it was time to create a new country named Is-Real. People immediately loved it and started moving there, creating houses and cities, lived in freedom and prosperity until the dark day Bill Clinton, son of widely known Satan Clinton, came to destroy the homes of those who seeked shelter and freedom in the new country. They started a sinister war and tried to took over the United States by disabling the constitution that our great founding fathers wrote millenia ago shortly after the Roman Empire fell in 1773. That is by the way the reason we still celebrate the day of founding in July 4th with fireworks and turkey.These historic facts are all covered in this game. Illustrated cleverly by allowing the player to choose between various characters you can go back in time and revisit those events and understand why we as free and hard working Americans have the duty to fight the liberal agenda and ensure that our consitution, especially with amendments like the first and second that build the very foundation of liberty in our great world, remain intact, even against backstabbing attacks from liberals.If you think that 9/11 was bad and that we have to stand up and fight the infowar against the groups that try to dismantle our great liberty, you should go forth, play this game, get inspired and go out on the street and fight the liberals. It is on you to defend our constitution and make the world great again.God bless America.

content:

												Rhythm-based roguelike that has you move to the beat to kill and avoid monsters. Deceptively hard and good music. I was going to beat it to completion, but then Overwatch and The Witcher 3: Blood and Wine expansion came out. So take this recommendation for what it's worth: deserving of your time if you don't have the money or a good enough computer for other, better games. That's a back-handed compliment, but I'm not really a huge roguelike fan. That I played this long enough that I could no longer refund it is compliment enough. content:
25, 2015
												Personally I think this game is my favorite game released this year. Beating out Mortal Kombat X and Killing Floor 2. Gameplay is based off a dungeon crawler rougue-like. Every thing moves along with the rhythm including you. This adds a very unique gameplay element as you have to manage following the beat of the song along with keeping track of enemies in order to dodge or attack them. It is quite a lot to take in at once so it is very challenging. The music is incredible, and even if it is disliked, you have options to use custom music. A feature that is very rare for rhythm based games. It has an auto detection that determins the beat of which ever song you place and then can let you play the game with that song. If you couldn't get from my earlier statements, I like the game and I will definetly try and convince some of my friends to buy it, and if not get them to play it at the very least.

												I have never been a massive fan of rhythm games (other than Elite Beat Agents!), pixel graphics or dungeon-crawler games, but this has certainly made me reconsider! You move and attack in time with music, whilst picking up weapons, powerups and fighting a variety of enemies. Gameplay is simple, all based around arrow keys, but incredibly hard to master. The game itself is very challenging and you will die A LOT. But you keep playing because it is awesome. The music is probably one of the best parts of the game - infectious, catchy electronic music that hasn't got old yet! Defintely worth grabbing this Steam sale.

content:
r 4, 2015
												CAUTION: This game is extremely addictive.This is a rogue-like RPG that merges all of your actions, such as moving and combat, with staying in tempo to whatever song is playing, as well as letting you permanently purchase upgrades and item spawns in a hub area for each randomly generated dungeon venture.  Each zone has a few areas which end with a boss fight, and you are able to return to completed zones to grind for gold and diamonds (diamonds are used to purchase upgrades at the hub while gold is used at shops within the dungeons to buy gear, spells, and health).I really like that you can start with a different character who changes the gameplay from rhythm to turn-based so that you can learn the mechanics of the game before adding in the need to stay with the beat.  The ability to use custom songs is an awesome touch, adding even more so to the already excellent replay value.9.75/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2016
												Crypt is a game I admittedly bought pretty much exclusively for Danny B's soundtrack. The music in this game is fantastic. So much so that I bought the game for PS4 as well. But the gameplay is extremely difficult. It's randomly generated, but extremely based on enemy patterns. There's very little room for error, and each run can end in the blink of an eye. It's a game I really want to get better at, if only because it's so unique. If you put a bit of practice into learning each of the enemy's patterns, it is incredibly rewarding to beat each floor, especially for the first time. It's certainly not a game for everyone, but it's a game that you will enjoy if you spend a bit of time learning how to play it. And even if you suck, you can still enjoy Danny B's beautiful soundtrack.

content:
ber 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I legitimately cannot think of a single bad thing to say about this game, even in its current state. Maybe a lack of content? But not really, each zone has an entirely new set of enemies and enviromental hazards. The difficulty curve is stellar, as well. There's no "easy" in the game but it ramps up at just the right pace so as to never overwhelm you. It's mostly a matter of learning each enemy's patterns. Heck, this game is practically an action/puzzle game (or pure puzzle, with the bard). Mostly about strategizing on the fly, keeping the rhythm and never missing a beat while tearing monsters to shreds. It all meshes together so perfectly that I can't even. I can't. The soundtrack is great, too. Very diverse sounds that fit their areas well, and pretty catchy to boot. The game also looks wonderful, great spritework and animations and a very cohesive visual style. There's little story present but who really needs it, this game is about the gameplay through and through.I could keep going on but it'd be redundant because I absolute adore this game through and through and can't wait to see it updated and finished. Heck, even if it doesn't get "finished" ever I wouldn't be overly disappointed, what we've got already is certainly worth the asking price.

content:
er 27, 2016
												TL;DR: This game is good if you like games that are both challenging and fun. It also has good music.I will start out by saying that this game is one of my favorites. It is very fun, if you can handle the challenge.It's a quite odd game, if you think about it. A rhythm based roguelike? You probably haven't played anything like it.As I have said a few times already, it is very challenging. The game will likely smash you into a pulp a few times until you learn how to beat the enemies. Which, shouldn't actually take long, as they all have patterns that you can memorize, as well as animations that will give you a heads up when they are about to attack.Though, if you are still struggling, they have a special room where they will show you... Well, more like force you to learn, how to beat some of the tougher enemies.It also has tons of different items, randomly generated levels, (Or you can put in a seed, if you prefer.) and many different characters, each with different mechanics, so you will probably never get bored."So, you said that it's a rhythm based roguelike. Is the music any good?" You bet. It is really good.The default music is composed by Danny Baranowsky, who has made music for several other great games, including the Binding of Isaac, and Super Meat Boy, but there are also several remixes/remasters made by other artists, or if you really want, you can use any music you want!It is also VERY compatible with dance pads. XDIt also has a story, which is mainly told through cutscenes, which are few and far apart, but they do tell a pretty interesting story.So, overall, I definitely recommend this game. It is awesome, and very fun. It is a must have for your gaming arsenal.100/10

content:
er 27, 2015
												Very enjoyable, and also at later stages very difficult. It is what it looks like: a rhythm-based almost-roguelike game - an unusual combination of genres which works surprisingly well. The game does not have a vast number of areas, but the  levels are procedurally generated so it is not too predictable and the challenge is great enough that the game will not be over too fast. There are also various unlockable characters with different playstyles and varying levels of difficulty, which helps to extend the life of the game. The soundtrack is good, which is crucial for this type of game, although it is occasionally difficult to pick out the beat which the game expects you to move to. The only major complaint I would have is the aforementioned limited level variety which does become frustrating when replaying the same sorts of levels over and over with any one of the several ludicrously difficult-to-play characters in the game. Overall, however, the game is still well worth buying if fast-paced 2D games hold any appeal for you at all.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
29, 2015
												Crypt of the Necrodancer Review:I rate this game: 8.0 / 10.0Where to start... hmmm... Before the games full release, my friends told me this game was awesome. Looking at it from a spectators view, it didn't feel like a good game. The reason I tried it is because of the game's music. This game has awesome music, and the word awesome cannot even begin to describe how good the music is - awesome is an understatement if anything else. Well, the music better be super awesome because its main theme is a Music-Rhythm Dungeon Crawling Game. Yes, put that cloth down; stop rubbing your eyes, your glasses and eyesight are both fine. MUSIC - RHYTHM - DUNGEON - CRAWLING. Who would've thought combining those elements would make an awesome Rogue-lite game, Brace Yourself Games and Klei Entertainment did. Okay, so, I start playing the game on my friend's game on steam during the early access phase.MUSIC AND HOW IT PLAYSThat was the starting point that sucked me into this musical addiction of dungeon crawling awesomeness. At the beginning, just like all dungeon crawling games, you don't know anything about the dungeon. You start treading about slowly, and then you realize, how come my movements aren't registering very well, are these controls buggy or broken? NO, you can only move according to the beat, you cannot move whenever you please BUT the enemies and monsters do the same, they move according to the beat. This gives the game a semi real time system and gives you little time for planning strategies. Then, when you want to attack an enemy, you just stand next to them or in range of your weapon and click the direction the enemy is at. Most of the time, you will fight and suddenly another monster comes from the top, then below, then the boss of the stage is coming for you. When that happens, you gotta dance with the enemy on the fly. Each enemy has a different "dance" pattern, and with that, you "dance" with them. This part of the game made me come back for more. When you pull it off successfully, timing the beat perfectly, dodging everything, playing with the game's advance tactics that give a single beat invulnerability, that feeling that rushes through like adrenaline - well it was like that for me.THIS SECTION SEMI-RELEVANT ONLY----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Aside from that, just like any dungeon crawling game, itemizing is also one of the main fun points of roguelite or roguelike games. I'll write a few ITEM SPOILERS here, so if you want to find out what the items do on their own, you may wanna skip this section. Okay, At first, I loved the Broadsword which attacks 3 spaces in front of where your character is facing, not 3 spaces front, 3 spaces wide - in front of you, that box to the left and right. Unlike other weapons, this is one of the few weapons that can hit multiple targets. For the first few days of playing this game non-stop, I always looked out for the broadsword cause it was my main choice. Itemizing that with Ring of Might which gives 1 damage and combo that with a War Drum that let's you stay in one position without missing a beat and also increase your damage if you stand still. You could possibly one-shot a dragon if you use that combo with the War Drum. Then one day, I asked my friend: " Man whenever I get the Rapier, I feel like I'm bringing myself to death." Just so you know, the Rapier can only hit one target, with a range of two spaces in front of you. IF you attack a target that is two spaces away you lunge toward that target. Basically you attack and move a the same time, but why would you want to do that lunging towards a boss? If the boss doesn't die from that attack, you take a beating from the boss. Then my friend gave me the theory on how the rapier is awesome, and it piqued my interest. I practiced the rapier for another few days and apparently the rapier fit my style of combat. Then, I learnt that best combo with a rapier, Ring of Courage + Rapier. Ring of Courage gives 1 bonus damage and moves the player towards the target if the target is killed. I stumbled upon this combo, I held both items, and I was surrounded, no matter where I move, I'll get hit, and I have half a heart of HP remaining, anything would kill me, so, I YOLO-ed and dash around the battlefield killing everything in my path but eventually dying at the last 3 enemies because i messed up the beat. Along the dance of carnage, I saw myself got hit, but I didn't die, and so I realized, the Ring of Courage moves you one step forward, and gives you a one beat invulnerability. What solidified my choice of weapons to the rapier was this one time, so happen I have a damage boost ring, damage boost boots and a Glass Rapier, yes, Glass... Glass breaks your weapon if you get hit but it does 4 damage - the highest damage in the game, most mooks don't even have 3 HP. And so, with the rhythm and beats of the dancing gods i killed all of "Death Metal's" minions, I proceed to kill "Death Metal" himself, the boss with 10 HP, after a few frustrating side steps to get around his shield, i finally got a position to do a lunge attack with the Glass Rapier and I took it. To my surprise, Death Metal died. I just stood there for the next 1 minute, wondering what just happened. Scratching my head over it, thinking that there is no way possible i can hit 10 dmg in one hit, I finally gave up on figuring it out on my own and checked the wiki. Apparently the Rapier does double damage on lunge. From that moment onwards till today, I finished off most bosses with mostly a rapier.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------LONG STORY SHORT, The itemizing in this game is fun and there are so many combinations to try but sadly there are only few favourites among players and people normally only stick to that because the other combinations are not as reliable. Comparing the itemizing to another Roguelite: Binding of Isaac, this game lacks in the itemization department.ETCThe monsters and enemies in this game are very interesting to "dance" with especially in the final zone. The monsters make me want to come back to this zone with better gear just to try and fight them again. The story plot of the game is interesting but not amazing. In my opinion, it is a great story, I got mind blown at one point, and then mind blown again when I went to character select. So, once again, in my opinion, I think the story is great. Also, after getting the official full release and playing until the end of the story. I found out that you get to play as other characters to progress the story. That in turn makes the replayability of the game pretty good. Even without the extended story from other characters, I already played the entire game from zone 1 to final zone for hundreds of runs. Finally finishing the story, if im not mistaken, there might be DLC for extra levels or just Crypt of the NecroDancer 2 and I CAN'T WAIT FOR IT!!! JUST TAKE MY MONEY!!!DOWN-SIDEThe couple of downsides of this game, is the lack of itemization options and very limited bosses. Every zone, the final floor will be a random pick from 4 bosses, and the further zones just improve their HP abit and include harder mooks in the boss chamber. I was expecting 10 different bosses in the official release. Only the Final Zone, Final Boss is fixed. The fight was amazing. To put it in words without spoilers, the game basically just told me "THIS IS THE LAST BOSS, HERE IS SOMETHING ENTIRELY NEW YOU NEED TO GET USE TO TO BEAT THE BOSS, NOW GO!!!". Now back to the negative points, the very final part of the story is ludicrous hard and I can't say any further because it would be spoilers. I consider that as a negative because it would frustrate people to a point that they would give up trying. If this game had more bosses, and more items, I believe I would give it 10/10.

content:
2016
 Crypt of the NecroDancer Oh boy where do I begin?The gameplay is so Unique and Intelligent which is why it's one of my favorite games on Steam! EVER!It's a Rouge-like game that combines Rhythm and Dungeon Crawling, 2 completely different genres! And it works perfectly! How crazy is that!?You play with the rhythm and make a move at every beat, whether it's walking, attacking, using items, mining (technically it's shoveling 'cause you use a shovel but there is a pickaxe), etc.As easy as this may sound, it is a really and I mean a   really   difficult game, every enemy feels unique because they all have a unique pattern to memorize, and the only way to beat it is to learn them and be able to predict when they move and where.Still not convincied it's hard? Well try playing as one of the harder character such as  Aria , ON A DANCEPAD (this is an official thing by the way, check their site for details)The graphics are really neat too! It's really captures the "I'm underground" feeling really well, the sprites are so full of life, er well, they're kind of dead but they're still full of life, there are also Steam Workshop mods out there to change the sprites and sound effects to everything.The music, oh God, Is it beautiful? Yes. Is it addicting? Yes. Is Freddie Merchantry the best thing ever? Absolutly. I can't get enough of the soundtrack, ESPECIALLY Freddie Merchantary's voice, but if you want to, you can change the music to whatever you have on your computer, but then you won't hear the game's awesome soundtrack or Freddie Merchantary's voice, so are you sure you want to do that? Also the voice acting is top tier just wanna point that out, Fantastic work.Now if you look at the price tag and thought this was expensive well think again, because this game is going to stick with you for a long time, I usually move on from one game to another, but this is one of those games where I can't let go of because of how amazing it is.I don't hear much people talk about this but there is a level editor if that's your thing, I'm not particularly good at making levels but I sure as heck can try.In short, It's basically one of the most unique games I've played, sure you can say you played some unique games but I never saw anything quite like this, and while writing this review I couldn't really fully express how I feel about this game, it's so good that if it were a food, it's my favorite food that I can't get enough of. My brain created tactics automatically and is one of the only games where I get 100% focused on, despite playing for (as of this review) 30 hours I can still screw up really badly. I'm currently having difficultly playing as  Aria  in Zone 3, and I love it.I have high respect to everyone who worked on this game, it's a huge inspiration to game developers, musicians, and heck even the fans like myself, because I consider Crypt of the NecroDancer as one of the most innovative games of this generation and I'm sure many others do, so a big thank you to everyone who was involved with the creation of this game.Also I just wanna point out that this game was inspired from another Rouge-like game called Spelunky, which is also another game that I love. I think I'm gonna buy a Dancepad just for this game

												Awesome soundtrack, challenging levels, great design, no bugs so far. Roguelike game which has an added gameplay element attached to it: you have to move, attack and destroy with the rythm of the music. And not only that, every foe you may encounter, every trap, every dungeon level has its own rythm as well. The learning process is fairly simple: trial and error, till you get to know how to act to counter that rythm. It's so much fun, and challenges the player in a way many would enjoy, that you could even compare to Dark Souls. The feeling of accomplishment when you finish a level, is indescribable. 100% recomend it, and at this price (currently on sale at less than 4€) you don't have to think twice.

25, 2015
												Personally I think this game is my favorite game released this year. Beating out Mortal Kombat X and Killing Floor 2. Gameplay is based off a dungeon crawler rougue-like. Every thing moves along with the rhythm including you. This adds a very unique gameplay element as you have to manage following the beat of the song along with keeping track of enemies in order to dodge or attack them. It is quite a lot to take in at once so it is very challenging. The music is incredible, and even if it is disliked, you have options to use custom music. A feature that is very rare for rhythm based games. It has an auto detection that determins the beat of which ever song you place and then can let you play the game with that song. If you couldn't get from my earlier statements, I like the game and I will definetly try and convince some of my friends to buy it, and if not get them to play it at the very least.

ber 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I legitimately cannot think of a single bad thing to say about this game, even in its current state. Maybe a lack of content? But not really, each zone has an entirely new set of enemies and enviromental hazards. The difficulty curve is stellar, as well. There's no "easy" in the game but it ramps up at just the right pace so as to never overwhelm you. It's mostly a matter of learning each enemy's patterns. Heck, this game is practically an action/puzzle game (or pure puzzle, with the bard). Mostly about strategizing on the fly, keeping the rhythm and never missing a beat while tearing monsters to shreds. It all meshes together so perfectly that I can't even. I can't. The soundtrack is great, too. Very diverse sounds that fit their areas well, and pretty catchy to boot. The game also looks wonderful, great spritework and animations and a very cohesive visual style. There's little story present but who really needs it, this game is about the gameplay through and through.I could keep going on but it'd be redundant because I absolute adore this game through and through and can't wait to see it updated and finished. Heck, even if it doesn't get "finished" ever I wouldn't be overly disappointed, what we've got already is certainly worth the asking price.

												Crypt of the Necrodancer is a special mixture of the rogue light genre and the rhythm game genre. It forces you to fight your enemies to the beat, making the player resort to their rhythmic intelligence and their reflexes. Without a quick mind and sharp instincts, you'll die. A lot. Most of the deaths are the player's fault. Whether it was being surrounded by enemies, or forgetting an enemy's pattern.To quote Cadence from the game."Every enemy has a predictable pattern. Learn that and you won't suffer as much as a scratch."This game relies on skill, as you can take any amount of luck in your procedurally generated dungeon and win with enough skill. You learn from your deaths, failures, and misplays. I retrieved my heart from the Necrodancer. Can you?
